revision.text:
{{Infobox officeholder |office = Member of the [[Council of the District of Columbia]]
from Ward 7 |term_start = January 2, 1993 |term_end = January 2, 2005 |predecessor = [[H. R. Crawford]] |successor = [[Vincent C. Gray|Vincent Gray]] |birth_date = {{birth date and age|1956|5|17}} |birth_place = [[Indianapolis]], [[Indiana]], U.S. |death_date = |death_place = |party = [[Democratic Party (United States)|Democratic]] |alma_mater = [[Wabash College]] {{small|([[Bachelor of Arts|BA]])}}
[[Howard University]] {{small|([[Juris Doctor|JD]])}} }} '''Kevin P. Chavous''' (born May 17, 1956) is an attorney, author, education reform activist, and former [[Democratic Party (United States)|Democratic Party]] politician in [[Washington, D.C.]], in the United States. He served as a member of the [[Council of the District of Columbia]] from January 1993 to January 2005, and was an unsuccessful candidate for [[Mayor of the District of Columbia]] in 1998. ==Early life and education== Chavous was born in [[Indianapolis, Indiana]], the son of Bettie J. and Harold P. Chavous. His father was a [[pharmacist]] and his mother a civil rights activist. Chavous was the oldest of four children. His first job was working at Chavous Drugs, his father's drug store, sweeping and mopping floors and stocking shelves.{{cite news |last=Sanchez |first=Rene |title=Stability, Success Mark Chavous's Life |work=The Washington Post |date=September 1, 1998 |page=D01}} Chavous was educated at [[Brebeuf Jesuit Preparatory School]] in Indianapolis and [[Wabash College]] in [[Crawfordsville, Indiana]], where he earned a [[bachelor's degree]] in [[political science]].{{cite news |title=Kevin Chavous, Democrat |work=The Washington Post |date=September 9, 2004 |page=T15}} While at Wabash, he was [[NCAA Division III]] District All-American in basketball.{{cite news |title=Democratic Primary: Council Ward 7 |work=The Washington Post |date=September 7, 2000 |page=J18}} Chavous also earned a [[Juris doctor|JD]] degree from the [[Howard University School of Law]] in Washington, D.C., where he was president of his law school class. He is a member of [[Kappa Alpha Psi]] fraternity. ==Community activism== After graduating from law school, Chavous became a [[personal injury lawyer]] for the D.C. law firm of Cadeaux & Tagliere. The Chavouses and their children lived in [[Hillcrest, Washington, D.C.|Hillcrest]], an affluent neighborhood in [[Southeast, Washington, D.C.|Southeast Washington]] on the District-[[Maryland]] border. In May 1988, Chavous was elected to the [[District of Columbia Democratic State Committee]], representing Ward 7.{{cite news |last=Sherwood |first=Tom |title=Jackson's Landslide Falls Short of Hopes: Lack of D.C. Organization Cited |work=The Washington Post |date=May 5, 1988 |page=D1 |postscript=none}}; {{cite news |title=District Election Primary Results: Democratic Primary |work=The Washington Post |date=May 19, 1988 |page=J6}} The following year, [[Pepco]], an [[electric power]] [[public utility]], proposed a significant expansion of its coal-fired power generating plant on the edge of the [[River Terrace, Washington, D.C.|River Terrace]] neighborhood in Ward 7. The River Terrace Community Organization, a group representing citizens living in the neighborhood, opposed the plant, and Chavous agreed to represent the group in court ''[[pro bono]]''.{{cite news |last=Hamilton |first=Martha M. |title=Expansion of Pepco Plant In NE Washington Opposed |work=The Washington Post |date=February 15, 1989 |page=D3}}{{cite news |last=Loeb |first=Vernon |title=Chavous Touts Record on Schools |work=The Washington Post |date=August 25, 1998 |page=D1}} Pepco cancelled the expansion in 1991, and Chavous gained significant visibility for his work. Chavous also joined the national board of directors of [[Brady Campaign|Handgun Control, Inc.]], a group working for strong federal [[gun control]] legislation.{{cite news |title=Kevin Chavous |work=The Washington Post |date=September 12, 1998 |page=DC2}} ==1992 council race and term== ===1992 council race=== The Pepco fight launched Chavous' political career. Chavous, who by now was hosting a once-a-week program on legal issues on radio station [[WCSP-FM|WDCU-FM]], announced in May 1992 that he would challenge incumbent Ward 7 Councilmember [[H. R. Crawford]].{{cite news |last=Harriston |first=Keith |title=Kelly Spokesman Rebuts Accusation That Homicide Figures Were Withheld |work=The Washington Post |date=May 28, 1992 |page=J3}} Crawford, ''[[The Washington Post]]'' reported, was facing strong criticism from voters from his legislative achievements and three Democratic [[primary election]] challengers.{{cite news |last=Harriston |first=Keith |title=Crawford Battling Challengers and Criticism |work=The Washington Post |date=September 8, 1992 |page=D8}}{{cite news |last=Harriston |first=Keith |title=Chavous Taps Discontent, Ousts Crawford in Ward 7: Batch of Endorsements Can't Save Incumbent |work=The Washington Post |date=September 16, 1992 |page=A14}} Chavous waged an intensive grassroots campaign to unseat Crawford. According to ''The Washington Post'', Chavous visited every single-family residence in Ward 7 personally, either speaking with members of the household or leaving behind campaign literature. On September 15, 1992, Chavous unseated Crawford, 4,866 votes (41.7 percent) to 4,266 (37 percent). In the [[general election]] on November 3, 1992, Chavous easily defeated [[Republican Party (United States)|Republican]] candidate Johnnie Scott Rice, 96 percent to 4 percent.{{cite news |last=Sanchez |first=Rene |title=District Rejects Death-Penalty Measure |work=The Washington Post |date=November 4, 1992 |page=A33 |postscript=none}}; {{cite news |title=District: Key to the Vote Results |work=The Washington Post |date=November 5, 1992 |page=C11}} ===First council term=== Chavous was sworn in on January 2, 1993.{{cite news |last=Sanchez |first=Rene |title=Barry Takes Office As Supporters Cheer: Others on Council, School Board Sworn In |work=The Washington Post |date=January 3, 1993 |page=B3}} During his first term on the council, Chavous aligned with Ward 2 council member [[Jack Evans (D.C. politician)|Jack Evans]] (elected in 1991), At-Large council member [[William Lightfoot]] (elected in 1988), and Ward 6 council member [[Harold Brazil]] (elected in 1991) to form a caucus known as the "Young Turks". Together, they successfully opposed tax increases sought for the city by Mayor [[Sharon Pratt Kelly]].{{cite news |last=Woodlee |first=Yolanda |title=In Ward 7, Council 'Baby' Grows Up Fast |work=The Washington Post |date=December 5, 1993 |page=B1}} On June 22, 1993, an unidentified gunman sprayed the public swimming pool at the Benning Park Recreation Center with fire from a semiautomatic weapon. Panic-stricken children and adults fled the pool, and six children were wounded by gunfire.{{cite news |last1=Castaneda |first1=Ruben |last2=Loose |first2=Cindy |title=Gunman Opens Fire at D.C. Pool; 6 Children Wounded in Chaotic Scene |work=The Washington Post |date=June 23, 1993 |page=A1}} The incident highlighted the high level of gun violence in Ward 7, and ''The Washington Post'' said Chavous was thrust into the citywide spotlight by it. Chavous personally brought his two young children to the pool (which had seen almost no visitors since the attack) on June 29 to demonstrate the pool's safety and send a message of defiance to drug dealers and violent criminals.{{cite news |last=O'Donnell |first=Santiago |title=With Pride, Fear, They Jump Back In |work=The Washington Post |date=June 30, 1993 |page=B1}} On September 26, 1993, four-year-old Launice Smith was shot in the head and head (and survived) while her family watched a pick-up football game at Weatherless Elementary School in the [[Fort Dupont]] neighborhood in Ward 7. Smith was injured when four gunmen emerged from a nearby woods and then hunted down and executed 20-year-old Kervin Brown in what [[Metropolitan Police Department of the District of Columbia|D.C. police]] said was part of an ongoing battle between rival drug gangs.{{cite news |last1=Brown |first1=DeNeen L. |last2=Castaneda |first2=Ruben |title=Police Say Turf Wars Fueled Day of Violence |work=The Washington Post |date=September 27, 1993 |page=A1}} Once more, Chavous was seen as one of the most important political leaders responding to violence in the city. On September 29, he announced for the formation of a 20-member task force on public safety and began pushing for Ward 7 residents to police their own neighborhoods and report drug dealing, crime, and violence.{{cite news |last=Harris |first=Hamil |title=SE Communities Uniting to Battle Decay |work=The Washington Post |date=September 30, 1993 |page=DC1}} Chavous later called the task force one of the most important developments of his first term. Among other key legislative accomplishments in his first term was a 1993 act allowing the city to seize abandoned vehicles{{cite news |last=Harris |first=Hamil |title=Bill Takes Aim at Trash Disposal Offenders |work=The Washington Post |date=April 15, 1993 |page=J1 |postscript=none}}; {{cite news |last=Sewell |first=Chan |title=Liquor Bill Dominates D.C. Council Session |work=The Washington Post |date=December 6, 2000 |page=B7}} and 1994 legislation that enacted a temporary ban on new liquor licenses for stores selling beer by the can (so-called "takeout beer").{{cite news |last=Duggan |first=Paul |title=Community Assault On Crime Is Urged |work=The Washington Post |date=December 23, 1993 |page=J3 |postscript=none}}; {{cite news |last=Woodlee |first=Yolanda |title=D.C. Agrees To Curtail Liquor: Council to Impose License Moratorium In Four City Wards |work=The Washington Post |date=February 4, 1994 |page=A1}} He and the other Young Turks also successfully enacted in 1995 a $70 million cut in the wages earned by [[trade union]] members under the city's version of the [[Davis–Bacon Act]]. (The cut was temporary, and expired in 1996.) Chavous' legislative activism declined significantly over his first term. Chavous told ''The Washington Post'' in February 1996 that "it has proved easier to wait for someone else, be it the mayor or the control board, to propose hard solutions," according to journalists Howard Schneider and David A. Vise. He unsuccessfully supported in 1995 a package of [[conservatism|conservative]] Republican Party proposals to significantly change the way the city provided [[welfare]] benefits, and a plan to create an independent school board to approve and oversee [[Charter schools in the United States|charter schools]]. One significant (and eventually successful) change he advocated was the creation of a [[District of Columbia Financial Control Board]] to save the city from bankruptcy. He was one of the first council members to call for federal oversight (in early 1995), although later in the year he refused to vote to cut big-ticket items such as unemployment benefits or the city's summer youth jobs program.{{cite news |last1=Schneider |first1=Howard |last2=Vise |first2=David A. |title=Tough on Talk, Soft on Action |work=The Washington Post |date=February 19, 1996 |page=E1}} Congress created a financial control board in April 1995.{{cite news |last=Janofsky |first=Michael |title=Congress Creates Board to Oversee Washington, D.C. |work=The New York Times |date=April 8, 1995 |accessdate=November 1, 2015 |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1995/04/08/us/congress-creates-board-to-oversee-washington-dc.html}} ==1996 reelection and second council term== ===1996 council race=== Chavous sought reelection in 1996. He faced a challenger in the Democratic primary election, [[District of Columbia State Board of Education|District of Columbia Board of Education]] member Terry Hairston. In July 1996, Hairston challenged Chavous' right to be on the ballot. D.C. election law required a candidate to obtain signatures from at least 250 voters in a ward in order to run for a district council seat in that ward. Chavous submitted signatures from 574 voters. But D.C. law also required that all individuals gathering such signatures be residents of the District of Columbia, and Hairston alleged that Chavous campaign worker Calvin S. Hawkins did not meet that condition.{{cite news |title=Chavous Faces Ballot Challenge |work=The Washington Post |date=July 25, 1996 |page=B4}} The [[District of Columbia Board of Elections]] ruled in Chavous' favor on July 30, 1996.{{cite news |title=Challenger's Complaint Rejected |work=The Washington Post |date=July 31, 1996 |page=B5}} In the Democratic primary held on September 10, 1996, Chavous easily defeated Hairston and another challenger, Eddie Rhodes, winning 68 percent of the vote.{{cite news |last=Williams |first=Vanessa |title=Brazil Sweeps Away Yeldell's Challenge |work=The Washington Post |date=September 11, 1996 |page=A1 |postscript=none}}; {{cite news |title=District: Primary Election Results |work=The Washington Post |date=September 11, 1996 |page=A14}} Chavous won 90 percent of the vote in the general election on November 5, easily beating [[D.C. Statehood Green Party|D.C. Statehood Party]] candidate Durand A. Ford (6 percent) and Republican Party candidate James Bernard Miles (3 percent).{{cite news |last=Williams |first=Vanessa |title=Brazil, Schwartz Win Handily In D.C. Council At-Large Race |work=The Washington Post |date=November 6, 1996 |page=B13 |postscript=none}}; {{cite news |title=Results: District of Columbia |work=The Washington Post |date=November 6, 1996 |page=B18}} ===Second council term=== On December 30, 1996, Chavous was elected chairman of the Council's Committee on Education, Libraries and Recreation.{{cite news |last=Harris |first=Hamil R. |title=Clarke Hospitalized For Tests, Aide Says |work=The Washington Post |date=December 31, 1996 |page=B3}} Ward 3 council member [[Kathleen Patterson|Kathy Patterson]], a veteran education activist, also fought for the chairmanship. Patterson strongly criticized Chavous' commitment to educational reform, but Council Chairman [[David A. Clarke]] awarded the post to Chavous after he publicly declared education reform to be the biggest issue facing the sity. Patterson, however, won an agreement that stripped jurisdiction over labor issues from Chavous' committee and gave it to the Committee on Government Operations (chaired by Patterson). During his first year in office, the [[District of Columbia Public Schools]] undertook an emergency $50 million project to repair leaking and structurally unsound roofs at several public schools. The project was significantly mismanaged, and forced a delay in the opening of the school year. Chavous ordered a hearing on the issue in September 1997, but a significant number of parents of schoolchildren complained he had not provided enough oversight and acted too late.{{cite news |last=Williams |first=Vanessa |title=Chavous Takes Some Heat Over D.C. Council Inaction: His Leadership on Schools Crisis Is Questioned |work=The Washington Post |date=September 29, 1997 |page=B1}} In March 1997, Chavous sponsored another significant piece of legislation, a resolution disapproving a construction contract for the highly controversial [[Barney Circle#Barney Circle Freeway fight|Barney Circle Freeway]].{{cite news |last=Loeb |first=Vernon |title=Norton Declares Barney Circle Freeway a Dead End |work=The Washington Post |date=March 5, 1997 |page=B1}} Chavous also opposed construction of a [[Walter E. Washington Convention Center|new convention center]] in the city. As late as May 27, 1998, Chavous said he had not decided whether to support the project.{{cite news |last1=Harris |first1=Hamil R. |last2=Woodlee |first2=Yolanda |title=Candidates Feel Their Way in Debate |work=The Washington Post |date=May 28, 1998 |page=D4}} But he voted to oppose it during the council's vote on June 2, arguing that plans to build a convention center smaller than many then under construction was "a plan to build a second-tier convention center".{{cite news |last1=Montgomery |first1=David |last2=Evans |first2=Judith |title=Convention Center Wins Council Vote: District Would Finance $685 Million Project |work=The Washington Post |date=June 3, 1998 |page=A1}} After his losing mayoral campaign, Chavous became what ''The Washington Post'' called a "frequent critic" of the new mayor, Anthony A. Williams,{{cite news |last1=Cottman |first1=Michael H. |last2=Lipton |first2=Eric |title=Mayor's Budget Plan Is Met With Anger |work=The Washington Post |date=March 16, 1999 |page=B01}} and had "the chilliest relationship with the mayor" of any Council member.{{cite news |last=Williams |first=Vanessa |title=Mayor, Council Struggle to Patch Relations |work=The Washington Post |date=August 23, 1999 |page=B1}} Chavous was an early supporter of Councilmember [[Carol Schwartz]]'s tax cut package in March 1999,{{cite news |last=Williams |first=Vanessa |title=Schwartz Proposes Tax Cuts |work=The Washington Post |date=March 4, 1999 |page=B6}} which became law in May.{{cite news |last1=Williams |first1=Vanessa |last2=Vise |first2=David A. |title=D.C. Council Approves Massive Tax Cuts |work=The Washington Post |date=May 5, 1999 |page=A1 |postscript=none}}; {{cite news |last1=Williams |first1=Vanessa |last2=Vise |first2=David A. |title=Delighted D.C. Council Adopts Budget |work=The Washington Post |date=May 12, 1999 |page=B1}} Chavous also led a nine-month effort to reconstitute and reform the D.C. Board of Education. After a long battle with Mayor Williams and other Council members, the Council approved a plan to reduce the size of the board, and make four of the nine members subject to mayoral appointment (with Council confirmation).{{cite news |last1=Wilgoren |first1=Debbi |last2=Moreno |first2=Sylvia |title=Williams Loses Bid For Control Of Schools |work=The Washington Post |date=January 19, 1999 |page=A1}} Voters were asked to approve the "hybrid" board, which they did so in a close vote in June 2000.{{cite news |last=Williams |first=Vanessa |title=D.C. School 'Hybrid' Approved |work=The Washington Post |date=February 18, 1999 |page=B1 |postscript=none}}; {{cite news |last=Blum |first=Justin |title=Outcome of D.C. School Board Vote Affirmed |work=The Washington Post |date=July 8, 1999 |page=B7}} According to ''The Washington Post'', the bruising school board battle helped and hindered Chavous politically. While his allies said it showed he could tackle tough problems, dissenters argued that Chavous avoided the real issues (lack of money for schools and crumbling infrastructure). Chavous blamed the lengthy legislative process on unnamed individuals who he said did not engage in good faith in the process, but critics argued that Chavous never engaged in the kind of political hardball that was needed to move the reform bill along faster. Larry Gray, legislative chairman of the D.C. Congress of PTAs, blamed Chavous for deep cuts in the school budget during the past four years, failures in the teacher certification program, and significant delays in getting technology into the classroom.{{cite news |last=Williams |first=Vanessa |title=For Chavous, Bruises in a Scuffle Over Schools |work=The Washington Post |date=February 29, 2000 |page=B1}} ===Private-sector work=== In late 1998, after his campaign for mayor, Chavous left Cadeaux & Tagliere and joined the law firm of [[Arent Fox|Arent, Fox, Kintner, Plotkin & Kahn]].{{cite news |last1=Williams |first1=Vanessa |last2=Fehr |first2=Stephen C. |title=Chavous Gets Wired Over His New Job |work=The Washington Post |date=December 16, 1999 |page=DC1}} Chavous left Arent Fox{{cite news |last=Saraoshn |first=Judy |title=Bridgestone/Firestone Opens D.C. Office |work=The Washington Post |date=March 22, 2001 |page=A27}} and was appointed Vice President of Communications for [[Covad]] Communications Group, a [[broadband]] provider, in December 1999. But he left that position after just a year. Citing his somehwat difficult reelection campaign, Chavous said he wanted to devote more time to his Council position.{{cite news |last1=Sewell |first1=Chan |last2=Woodlee |first2=Yolanda |title=Chavous Quitting Lobbyist Job |work=The Washington Post |date=December 14, 2000 |page=J2}} ==1998 mayoral campaign== As early as January 1997, ''The Washington Post'' said, Chavous was running an all-but-announced campaign for mayor{{cite news |last=Harris |first=Hamil R. |title=Amid the Politics, New Term Begins: Campaign Rhetoric, Barry Barbs Mark D.C. Council's Swearing-In |work=The Washington Post |date=January 3, 1997 |page=C1 |postscript=none}}; {{cite news |last=Harris |first=Hamil R. |title=Chavous the Crusader |work=The Washington Post |date=February 27, 1997 |page=DC1}} to unseat incumbent [[Marion Barry]]. As part of a staff shakeup to improve his election chances, Chavous fired Jim Ford, the veteran staff director of the Committee on Education, Libraries and Recreation.{{cite news |last1=Harris |first1=Hamil R. |last2=Wheeler |first2=Linda |title=He's Now a Chief of a Different Sort |work=The Washington Post |date=January 16, 1997 |page=J3}} Valerie Strauss of ''The Washington Post'' said Ford's dismissal "robbed the committee of its institutional memory and one of its most vocal advocates for school reform."{{cite news |last=Strauss |first=Valerie |title=Firing Leaves a Void; Council Employee Was Expert on Schools |work=The Washington Post |date=January 30, 1997 |page=DC1}} But although Chavous had worked diligently to improve his name recognition and standing with the public, he garnered just 7 percent of those likely voters polled by ''The Washington Post'' in May 1997.{{cite news |last1=Williams |first1=Vanessa |last2=Harris |first2=Hamil R. |title=What? Me Worry? The Mayor Shrugs Off the Polls |work=The Washington Post |date=May 22, 1997 |page=J1}} Chavous formally announced his campaign for mayor on February 10, 1998,{{cite news |last=Powell |first=Michael |title=Chavous Makes It Official, Enters D.C. Mayor's Race |work=The Washington Post |date=February 11, 1998 |page=B1}} and raised $117,000 in the first month of his campaign.{{cite news |title=Chavous Raises $117,000 in Mayor's Race |work=The Washington Post |date=March 12, 1998 |page=B3}} Chavous trailed the other leading candidate in the race, Jack Evans, who raised more than $307,000 since early December 1997, as well as restaurateur Jeffrey Gildenhorn, who doanted $400,000 of his own money to his own campaign. More than a third of the campaign contributions to the Chavous campaign came from individuals living outside the District of Columbia.{{cite news |last=Woodlee |first=Yolanda |title=Chavous Trails Evans in Donations |work=The Washington Post |date=March 19, 1998 |page=J1}} Chavous said in April 1998 that, if elected, he would focus heavily on education reform. He rejected [[school vouchers]], but promised to fire principals and teachers who did not meet performance standards and create a boarding school for troubled youth. He also said he would disband the police oversight group established by the Financial Control Board, and work to revive commercial areas throughout the city.{{cite news |last=Powell |first=Michael |title=Mayoral Bid Will Center On Schools, Chavous Says |work=The Washington Post |date=April 29, 1998 |page=B8}} He later said he would cut a number of taxes levied by the city, including the [[Corporate tax|corporate income tax]], and seek passage of a federal law that would replace the current progressive federal income tax on city residents with a [[flat tax|flat federal income tax]] of 15 percent.{{cite news |last=Powell |first=Michael |title=In D.C. Mayoral Race, Tax Cutting Takes Lead |work=The Washington Post |date=July 21, 1998 |page=A1}} He also proposed universal [[early childhood education]],{{cite news |last=Williams |first=Vanessa |title=Chavous's Emphasis Is Early Education |work=The Washington Post |date=August 8, 1998 |page=B6}} and significantly improved city services for Latino residents.{{cite news |last=Williams |first=Vanessa |title=Chavous Pledges Better Services for Latinos |work=The Washington Post |date=August 12, 1998 |page=B4}} By mid-May, a ''Post'' poll showed 29 percent of voters favoring a sixth Barry term. Harold Brazil had 16 percent, Kevin Chavous had 15 percent, and Jack Evans had 10 percent.{{cite news |last1=Loeb |first1=Vernon |last2=Morin |first2=Richard |title=Survey Shows Barry Ahead of the Pack |work=The Washington Post |date=May 19, 1998 |page=A1}} On May 21, Barry said he would not seek reelection.{{cite news |last1=Loeb |first1=Vernon |last2=Woodlee |first2=Yolanda |title=Barry Says He Won't Seek Another Term |work=The Washington Post |date=May 22, 1998 |page=A1}} The announcement was a boost for Chavous, as polling showed that Barry's supporters were most likely to support him over other mayoral candidates.{{cite news |last=Harris |first=Hamil R. |title=The Race Is On As D.C. Candidates Scurry to Win Over Barry Backers |work=The Washington Post |date=May 23, 1998 |page=F6}} However, on May 30, 1998, [[Anthony A. Williams]] entered the race for mayor. Williams was the city's Chief Financial Officer, a position created by the same federal legislation which created the Financial Control Board. Williams had helped steer the city toward financial solvency, and had proven immensely popular among residents.{{cite news |last=Vise |first=David A. |title=Financial Officer to Run for D.C. Mayor |work=The Washington Post |date=May 31, 1998 |page=A1}} By early June, the Chavous campaign had raised more than $260,000 in campaign donations in an attempt to reach its $750,000 goal; about 25 percent of the contributions came from non-District residents.{{cite news |last=Woodlee |first=Yolanda |title=Evans Is Far Ahead In Fund-Raising Race |work=The Washington Post |date=June 11, 1998 |page=D4}} On June 20, Chavous barely won a [[straw poll]] of Democrats in Ward 8.{{cite news |last=Fehr |first=Stephen C. |title=Mayor Finds Support in Southeast for Tax, Spending Priorities |work=The Washington Post |date=March 30, 2000 |page=B5}} Anthony Williams came in a close second, in what ''The Washington Post'' called a sign of weakening support for Chavous.{{cite news |last=Loeb |first=Vernon |title=Democrats In Ward 8 Tilt Slightly to Chavous |work=The Washington Post |date=June 21, 1998 |page=B14}} But nine days later, he won the endorsement of the Metropolitan Washington AFL–CIO, a broad coalition of trade unions.{{cite news |last=Powell |first=Michael |title=Chavous Wins Union Backing in Mayor's Race |work=The Washington Post |date=June 30, 1998 |page=D3}} On July 1, Vickey Wilcher, the manager of Chavous' mayoral campaign, quit amid rumors of infighting among Chavous' top aides. ''The Washington Post'' reported that several top campaign staff were angered by Chavous' "indecisiveness" over the convention center issue. They were also alarmed that Chavous had failed to win the Ward 8 endorsement, and they fought with other campaign managers over the direction of the Chavous effort.{{cite news |last=Williams |first=Vanessa |title=Chavous's Campaign Manager Quits Amid Reports of Discord |work=The Washington Post |date=July 2, 1998 |page=D5}} The campaign received another blow a few days later when the influential [[Washington Teachers Union]] broke with the AFL-CIO and endorsed Williams for mayor.{{cite news |last=Williams |first=Vanessa |title=Teachers Union Endorses Williams |work=The Washington Post |date=July 10, 1998 |page=B1}} In July, Chavous raised another $100,000 toward his campaign goal. But Anthony Williams raised more than $400,000—most of it in small donations from voters throughout the city.{{cite news |last=Woodlee |first=Yolanda |title=Williams Tops 3 Rivals In Recent Fund-Raising |work=The Washington Post |date=August 11, 1998 |page=B1}} Chavous also loaned his campaign $25,000.{{cite news |last=Woodlee |first=Yolanda |title=2 Lend Money to Their Coffers |work=The Washington Post |date=August 20, 1998 |page=J1}} As the primary season wound down, a ''Post'' poll released on September 3, 1998, showed Williams with 37 percent of the vote and Chavous with 20 percent.{{cite news |last=Morin |first=Richard |title=Poll Puts Williams in Front |work=The Washington Post |date=September 3, 1998 |page=DC6}} A few days later, the Washington Teachers Union, D.C. Construction and Building Trades Council, Washington Social Workers Association, D.C. Nurses' Association, and National Hispanic Law Enforcement Association accused Chavous of missing 37 percent of all Council sessions during his first term in office, an accusation Chavous strongly denied.{{cite news |last1=Cottman |first1=Michael H. |last2=Williams |first2=Vanessa |title=Williams, Chavous Trade Barbs About Participation, Responsibility |work=The Washington Post |date=September 9, 1998 |page=B4}} In the last month of the mayoral race, Williams raised $303,000 compared with just over $77,000 for Chavous. Chavous concluded the race having raised just $450,000 toward his goal of $750,000, and he had only $66,000 for the final week of the campaign compared to Williams' $97,500.{{cite news |last=Woodlee |first=Yolanda |title=Williams, Evans Lead Pack in Fund-Raising |work=The Washington Post |date=September 9, 1998 |page=B5}} Anthony Williams won the Democratic primary election held on September 15, 1998. Williams received 50 percent of the vote, with Chavous a distant second at 35 percent.{{cite news |last1=Powell |first1=Michael |last2=Cottman |first2=Michael H. |title=Williams Wins Mayoral Primary |work=The Washington Post |date=September 16, 1998 |page=A1}}{{Efn|Williams defeated Chavous in Ward 4 by just 300 votes, his narrowest margin in any of the city's eight wards.{{cite news |last1=Chan |first1=Sewell |last2=Leonnig |first2=Carol D. |title=Ward 4 Challenge Targets Key Williams Ally |work=The Washington Post |date=May 31, 2001 |page=T2}}}} Williams easily defeated Republican [[Carol Schwartz]] in the general election on November 4, 66 percent to 30 percent. He carried all eight wards by a solid margin.{{cite news |last1=Cottman |first1=Michael H. |last2=Woodlee |first2=Yolanda |title=Williams Wins Big in D.C. Mayor's Race |work=The Washington Post |date=November 4, 1998 |page=A1 |postscript=none}}; {{cite news |title=Result Chart: District of Columbia |work=The Washington Post |date=November 4, 1998 |page=A37}} ==2000 reelection and third term== ===2000 council race=== Chavous announced he would run for a third four-year term on the Council of the District of Columbia in June 2000.{{cite news |last=Woodlee |first=Yolanda |title=Incumbents, 19 Others Enter Council Primary |work=The Washington Post |date=July 6, 2000 |page=B4}} His primary campaign faced significant problems. In June, the Far Northeast/Southeast Council, a coalition of [[Advisory Neighborhood Commission]]s (ANC) and neighborhood civic associations, voted "no-confidence" in Chavous, saying he had been absent from too many community meetings and events and had failed to keep resident informed about major changes in their ward (such as the relocation of the D.C. Department of Employment Services and the opening of a new charter school). In late July, the Metropolitan Washington Council of the AFL-CIO declined to make an endorsement in the Ward 7 Council primary race, after the Washington Federation of Teachers accused Chavous of ignoring their input on education policy. (The teachers union also declined an endorsement in August.){{cite news |last1=Leonnig |first1=Carol D. |last2=Sewell |first2=Chan |title=Political Nitty-Gritty |work=The Washington Post |date=August 17, 2000 |page=J02}} By August 4, Chavous had only raised $2,100 in contributions, but spent more than $46,500. (He used funds left over from his 1998 mayoral race to reduce that deficit to just $7,100.){{cite news |last=Sewell |first=Chan |title=Chavous Accused of Inaction; Weak Fundraising a Sign, Foes Say |work=The Washington Post |date=August 16, 2000 |page=B2}} Four individuals also challenged Chavous in the Democratic primary: Rev. Robert B. Hunter of Atonement Episcopal Church; Mary D. Jackson, a [[United States Senate]] archivist and an ANC member; Durand A. Ford, a financial management consultant; and Gary R. Feenster, a computing analyst.{{cite news |last=Sewell |first=Chan |title=4 Underdogs Seek to Block Third Term for Chavous |work=The Washington Post |date=August 31, 2000 |page=DCE7}} By the end of August, Chavous had raised $6,000 in new contributions, and said he hoped to raise $20,000 more before the general election. Despite these problems, Chavous won the Democratic primary on September 12. He garnered 53 percent of the vote.{{Efn|A later press report pegged his margin at just 51 percent.}} His closest challenger was Rev. Robert B. Hunter, who received 33 percent of the vote.{{cite news |last=Sewell |first=Chan |title=Council Member Jarvis Ousted in D.C. Primary |work=The Washington Post |date=September 13, 2000 |page=A1}} Chavous' campaign problems eased during the general election. By October 10, he had raised $66,800, and had $14,000 in cash on hand for the remaining three weeks of the general election campaign. Chavous blamed his reduced electoral margin in the primary on "lingering anger" over the school board reform battle.{{cite news |last=Sewell |first=Chan |title=In D.C. Council's Ward Races, Democrats Enjoy Advantage |work=The Washington Post |date=November 1, 2000 |page=B5}} Chavous won the general election on November 7 with 87 percent of the vote. Write-in Republican candidate Johnnie Scott Rice won 12 percent.{{cite news |last=Sewell |first=Chan |title=Delegate, Council: Norton, Other Incumbents Have an Easy Night of It |work=The Washington Post |date=November 8, 2000 |page=A44 |postscript=none}}; {{cite news |title=Unofficial Returns: District of Columbia |work=The Washington Post |date=November 9, 2000 |page=B7}} ===Third council term=== Chavous continued to have a contentious relationship with Mayor Williams in his third term.{{cite news |last=Woodlee |first=Yolanda |title=Council Members Fault Report on Williams |work=The Washington Post |date=April 10, 2002 |page=B2}} ''The Washington Post'' claimed that Chavous was considering a mayoral run in 2002, and that his battles with Williams were motivated by the search for a campaign issue.{{cite news |last=Pierre |first=Robert E. |title=D.C. Mayor Smarting After Public Discord |work=The Washington Post |date=March 3, 2001 |page=B1 |postscript=none}}; {{cite news |last1=Chan |first1=Sewell |last2=Goldstein |first2=Avram |title=Council Finds It Hard to Speak Kindly of Mayor |work=The Washington Post |date=December 6, 2001 |page=T2 |postscript=none}}; {{cite news |last=Goldstein |first=Avram |title=Council Member Banishes Health Chief From Hearing |work=The Washington Post |date=December 11, 2001 |page=B2}} His relationship with Harold Brazil also broke down over Brazil's support for Williams. "Harold's just become a lapdog," Chavous said. "Harold just defends the mayor even when the mayor doesn't ask for support. Frankly, it's more than frustrating."{{cite news |last1=Sewell |first1=Chan |last2=Leonnig |first2=Carol D. |title=Democrat Committee's Reformist Leader Under Fire |work=The Washington Post |date=April 12, 2001 |page=T2}} Chavous was vocal on a number of issues in his third council term. He opposed repeal of council members' term limits (approved by voters in 1994),{{cite news |last1=Pierre |first1=Robert E. |last2=Chan |first2=Sewell |title=District Term Limits Tossed; Council Reverses Voters' Decision In Referendum |work=The Washington Post |date=June 6, 2001 |page=A1}} and supported a [[redistricting]] plan which expanded Ward 7 west of the [[Anacostia River]] (angering residents of [[Kingman Park]], who wished to remain part of Ward 6).{{cite news |last=Chan |first=Sewell |title=D.C. Redistricting Meets Resistance East of River |work=The Washington Post |date=June 11, 2001 |page=B1 |postscript=none}}; {{cite news |last1=Chan |first1=Sewell |last2=Bacon |first2=Perry, Jr. |title=Redrawn Wards Approved In D.C. |work=The Washington Post |date=June 20, 2001 |page=B1}} But [[Peggy Cooper Cafritz]], the highly influential president of the new school board, strongly criticized Chavous for failing to secure more funding for public schools,{{cite news |title=D.C. Council Approves Pared-Down Budget |work=The Washington Post |date=October 2, 2002 |page=B4}} and residents of Ward 7 were so upset with his failure to push for cleanup of abandoned lots that 20 of them dumped trash on Chavous' front lawn in January 2003.{{cite news |last=Nakamura |first=David |title=Residents, City Try New Paths to Take Back Vacant Areas |work=The Washington Post |date=January 27, 2003 |page=B1}} Chavous publicly stated he was considering another mayoral run in December 2001.{{cite news |last=Leonnig |first=Carol D. |title=D.C. Mayor to Run for Second Term |work=The Washington Post |date=December 20, 2001 |page=B1}} When Mayor Williams apologized publicly for ethical lapses in January 2002, local news media reported that this only boosted Chavous' interest in a campaign.{{cite news |last=Timberg |first=Craig |title=Williams's Mea Culpa Can't Quell Controversy |work=The Washington Post |date=January 13, 2002 |page=C1}} Lingering anger among residents on the east side of the city at the closing of [[District of Columbia General Hospital|D.C. General Hospital]] and those who lived in areas unaffected by the city's business resurgence led Chavous to publicly announce he was considering a run.{{cite news |last=Timberg |first=Craig |title=Chavous Ponders Slings and Arrows of New Mayoral Bid |work=The Washington Post |date=January 17, 2002 |page=T2}} In April 2002, as the filing deadline neared, Chavous admitted he had a growing interest in challenging Williams for the mayor's office{{cite news |last=Timberg |first=Craig |title=D.C. Mayor's Troubles Embolden Past Rivals |work=The Washington Post |date=April 24, 2002 |page=B1}} Chavous announced in May that he would make a decision by the end of the month, noting that his own poll showed he was "very well known and very well respected" and that the public held a much less negative view about him than Williams.{{cite news |last=Twomey |first=Steve |title=Mayor Has Critics But No Challenger For Nomination |work=The Washington Post |date=May 4, 2002 |page=B6}} A damper was put on expectations for a Chavous run in late May when a ''Post'' poll showed Chavous losing to Williams, 51 percent to 31 percent.{{cite news |last1=Timberg |first1=Craig |last2=Deane |first2=Claudia |title=Williams Losing Support Of Blacks |work=The Washington Post |date=May 26, 2002 |page=A1}} On June 6, Chavous announced he would not run for mayor.{{cite news |last=Timberg |first=Craig |title=Chavous to Pass On Race for Mayor |work=The Washington Post |date=June 7, 2002 |page=B5}} When a local court ruled that Williams had not submitted enough valid signatures to put himself on the ballot, Williams announced he would run as a write-in candidate in the Democratic Party primary. There was brief speculation by a number of political observers, ''The Washington Post'' said, that Chavous would enter the race.{{cite news |last=Timberg |first=Craig |title=Williams Scrambles as Ballot Ruling Energizes Race |work=The Washington Post |date=July 28, 2002 |page=A1}} But he did not. The biggest issue of Chavous' third term was school vouchers. Chavous had opposed vouchers in the past,{{cite news |last=Strauss |first=Valerie |title=President to Push Vouchers For D.C. |work=The Washington Post |date=February 8, 2003 |page=B1}} but by February 2003, ''The Washington Post'' reported, Chavous was much more interested in providing ways to given parents a choice in whether to send their child to public school, private school, or charter school. Chavous and Mayor Williams met with [[United States Secretary of Education|Secretary of Education]] [[Rod Paige]] on February 6, 2003, to discuss vouchers and other "choice" programs, during which time Paige pledged a voucher program would not be forced on the city.{{cite news |title=Metro: In Brief |work=The Washington Post |date=February 7, 2002 |page=B3}} After the meeting, Chavous said he had not yet decided if he would support vouchers or not. Chavous then began to significantly moderate his criticism of Williams.{{cite news |last1=Timberg |first1=Craig |last2=Woodlee |first2=Yolanda |title=Nobody Seems to Be Lining Up to Support Williams's Budget |work=The Washington Post |date=March 20, 2003 |page=T2}} By March 31, Chavous said that he had come to support vouchers, but only if the program were not forced on the city and only if federal (not city) funds were used to finance the program.{{cite news |last=Meyer |first=Eugene |title=Cafritz Is Criticized For Voucher Support |work=The Washington Post |date=March 31, 2003 |page=B2 |postscript=none}}; {{cite news |last1=Timberg |first1=Craig |last2=Blum |first2=Justin |title=Mayor Endorses Vouchers in D.C. |work=The Washington Post |date=May 2, 2003 |page=A1 |postscript=none}}; {{cite news |last=Hsu |first=Spencer |title=Foes Halt Vote on School Vouchers |work=The Washington Post |date=July 18, 2003 |page=A1 |postscript=none}}; {{cite news |last=Milbank |first=Dana |title=From Iran, the 'Thomas Paine of School Choice' |work=The Washington Post |date=September 3, 2003 |page=A15}} On February 8, 2003, President [[George W. Bush]] announced that he would seek federal legislation to impose a school voucher program on the city. As Bush's proposal was considered by the [[United States House of Representatives|House of Representatives]], Chavous and D.C.'s [[Non-voting members of the United States House of Representatives|Delegate to Congress]], [[Eleanor Holmes Norton]] (a strong opponent of vouchers), blamed one another for a series of snubs, missed meetings, and attacks.{{cite news |last=Blum |first=Justin |title=Mayor Pursues Vouchers, Public School Aid |work=The Washington Post |date=July 24, 2003 |page=B1}} By the time the measure moved to the [[United States Senate|Senate]] in September, Chavous (along with Mayor Williams and Board President Cafritz) was opposed on the voucher issue by a significant majority of elected officials in the city.{{cite news |last=Hsu |first=Spencer |title=Williams Touts Vouchers for D.C. Schools |work=The Washington Post |date=September 24, 2003 |page=B1}} The Senate passed the school voucher bill on January 23, 2004, and President Bush signed it into law. The legislation provided for a temporary, five-year experiment under which 1,700 low-income students would received up to $7,500 a year so that they could attend a private school in the city or nearby jurisdictions. Congress provided $14 million for the project.{{cite news |last1=Hsu |first1=Spencer |last2=Blum |first2=Justin |title=D.C. School Vouchers Win Final Approval |work=The Washington Post |date=January 23, 2004 |page=A1}} A second major educational issue which arose during Chavous' third term was another round of reform aimed at the D.C. Board of Education. On September 24, 2003, Mayor Williams announced that the city's public school system was so dysfunctional and provided such low-quality education that he was introducing legislation to strip the Board of nearly all its power. Control over the school system would be given to the mayor, who would have the right to hire and fire the superintendent, principals, teachers, and other workers and who would gain significant new powers to reconstitute programs, operations, curriculum, and schools. Although Chavous was working on his own bill to give the Council and mayor more power over the school system,{{Efn|Chavous' plan was still under development, but would give the District Council a [[line item veto]] over the public school budget.}} he immediately threw his support behind Williams' plan.{{cite news |last1=Timberg |first1=Craig |last2=Blum |first2=Justin |title=Williams Seeks School Takeover |work=The Washington Post |date=September 25, 2003 |page=A1}} But little action on the mayor's plan had been taken by January 2004. Chavous argued that Williams had not been forceful enough in making the case for his proposal, and journalist Craig Timberg linked Chavous' lack of activity on the measure to a reluctance to take on a controversial issue in an election year. (Chavous' own bill was also delayed, and he said it would not be ready until at least March 2004.){{cite news |last=Timberg |first=Craig |title=Mayor's Move to Take Over Schools Drags |work=The Washington Post |date=January 4, 2004 |page=C1}} Williams said he might seek a third term as mayor merely to fight for his school reform bill, if the council did not act more expeditiously.{{cite news |last=Timberg |first=Craig |title=Williams Considers Trying for a 3rd Term |work=The Washington Post |date=January 8, 2004 |page=B1}} In February 2004, Chavous announced he no longer supported the mayor's bill. The school district was without a superintendent, and Chavous argued that no individual would want the job if the council was considering such a significant change to the position. He also said that giving the mayor hiring and firing authority over the superintendent would require congressional approval or a voter referendum, and both processes would take too long.{{cite news |last=Blum |first=Justin |title=Chavous Shifts View on Schools |work=The Washington Post |date=February 13, 2004 |page=B1}} Chavous then introduced a bill which largely undid the 2000 reforms. The new bill provided for a nine-member board, with eight elected members (one from each ward) and a president elected citywide. Chavous' committee approved the bill in April 2004 without a hearing.{{cite news |last=Blum |first=Justin |title=Williams Rebuffed On School Takeover |work=The Washington Post |date=April 3, 2004 |page=B3 |postscript=none}}; {{cite news |last=Blum |first=Justin |title=Williams's School Plan Defeated |work=The Washington Post |date=April 21, 2004 |page=A1}} Although Mayor Williams submitted an altered form of his original proposal two weeks after the defeat,{{cite news |last=Blum |first=Justin |title=Williams Softening Schools Proposal |work=The Washington Post |date=April 25, 2004 |page=C1}} it was rejected in mid-May and the Chavous bill approved by the council in July on a close 7-to-6 vote.{{cite news |last=Blum |first=Justin |title=Mayor's School Takeover Defeated |work=The Washington Post |date=May 19, 2004 |page=B1 |postscript=none}}; {{cite news |last=Chan |first=Sewell |title=Hybrid School Board Retained |work=The Washington Post |date=July 14, 2004 |page=B1}} The last major issue of Chavous' third term on the council was funding for [[Nationals Park]]. [[Major League Baseball]] was willing to move the [[Montreal Expos]] to Washington, D.C., which had long sought a major-league baseball franchise, but only if the city built a modern, baseball-only stadium for the team. By early June 2003, most of the District Council opposed the initial financing plan submitted by Williams. Chavous was the lone undecided councilmember. (Harold Brazil was the only supporter.){{cite news |last1=Timberg |first1=Craig |last2=Fainaru |first2=Steve |title=Financing In Doubt For Stadium |work=The Washington Post |date=June 8, 2003 |page=C1}} Chavous supported the stadium plan only after he had lost the September 14 Democratic primary.{{cite news |last1=Kovaleski |first1=Serge F. |last2=Woodlee |first2=Yolanda |title=Council Majority Backs Proposal—With Reservations |work=The Washington Post |date=September 30, 2004 |page=A12}} But he remained largely quiet during council debates, and was still considered a swing vote by November.{{cite news |last=Nakamura |first=David |title=New Stadium Bill Adds Community Fund |work=The Washington Post |date=November 3, 2004 |page=B1}} On November 3, he provided the critical third vote on the council's Economic Development Committee, which approved the stadium deal.{{cite news |last=Nakamura |first=David |title=D.C. Council Panels Back Stadium Plan |work=The Washington Post |date=November 4, 2004 |page=B1}} Twenty-seven days later, he joined with a narrow majority on the council to win final approval for the project.{{cite news |last=Nakamura |first=David |title=Council Backs Waterfront Stadium |work=The Washington Post |date=December 1, 2004 |page=A1}} Chavous twice more voted to approve the stadium financing arrangement in December, when the financing mechanism was amended.{{cite news |last=Nakamura |first=David |title=Council Approves Altered Stadium Deal |work=The Washington Post |date=December 15, 2004 |page=A1 |postscript=1}}; {{cite news |last1=Nakamura |first1=David |last2=Heath |first2=Thomas |title=Amended Deal on Stadium Approved |work=The Washington Post |date=December 22, 2004 |page=A1}} His term in office ended on January 2, 2005, when Gray was sworn in.{{cite news |last=Weiss |first=Eric M. |title=Council's New Arrivals Push to Spread Revival |work=The Washington Post |date=January 3, 2005 |page=B1}} ===Other work=== Chavous rejoined Arent Fox in March 2001 as counsel, a part-time position in which he specialized in business law, government relations, and general litigation.{{cite news |last1=Sewell |first1=Chan |last2=Blum |first2=Justin |title=Council Candidate Brazile? Gore Aide Drops Hints |work=The Washington Post |date=May 10, 2001 |page=T2}} Chavous also took a job in 2002 as a partner at the law firm of [[Sonnenschein Nath & Rosenthal]], practicing education and government law.{{cite news |last=McElhatton |first=Jim |title=Legal Work Boosts Salaries |work=The Washington Times |date=June 1, 2004 |accessdate=November 4, 2015 |url=http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1G1-117462574.html}} Chavous also won an appointment as an adjunct faculty member at the [[Washington College of Law]] at [[American University]]. He taught education law during the spring 2001 term. In October 2017, Chavous was named [[K12 (company)|K12 inc.]]'s President of Academics, Policy and Schools.{{Cite news|url=https://marketbrief.edweek.org/marketplace-k-12/k12-inc-taps-school-choice-advocate-kevin-chavous-leadership-post/|title=K12 Inc. Taps School Choice Advocate Kevin Chavous for Leadership Post - Market Brief|date=2017-10-27|work=Market Brief|access-date=2018-02-22|language=en-US}} Prior to being named president, Chavous served on K12's board of directors. ==2004 failed reelection bid== Rumors that Chavous would face significant primary opposition should he run for reelection in 2004 emerged in March 2003. [[Vincent C. Gray]], former director of the D.C. Department of Human Services and the founding director of the D.C. chapter of [[Covenant House]], challenged incumbent Jeri Washington for the chairmanship of the Ward 7 Democrats. Gray easily won, 256 to 134. ''The Washington Post'' concluded that the loss reflected discontent with Chavous' tenure in office, and that there was widespread speculation that Gray would challenge Chavous for the Ward 7 council seat the following year. Several of the activists and donors who had backed Anthony Williams in his first race for mayor urged Gray to run against Chavous.{{cite news |last=Nakamura |first=David |title=Chavous Challenges Notion That He's Lost Touch |work=The Washington Post |date=September 8, 2004 |page=B1}} Gray launched his campaign to unseat Chavous on May 19, 2004,{{cite news |last1=Montgomery |first1=Lori |last2=Labbe |first2=Theola |title=Brazil Distances Himself From Mayor |work=The Washington Post |date=May 20, 2004 |page=T2}} and began waging what the ''Post'' called an "aggressive campaign".{{cite news |last=Woodlee |first=Yolanda |title=Allen Has $100,000 For Ward 8 Campaign |work=The Washington Post |date=August 11, 2004 |page=B1}} Gray was not Chavous' only challenger. Five other individuals had also filed for the seat (although none of them were expected to impact the race significantly). By the end of June, Gray had raised $1,235 in contributions. By the end of July, Chavous had raised $88,514 (all but $16,259 in May 2004){{cite news |last1=Montgomery |first1=Lori |last2=Woodlee |first2=Yolanda |title=For D.C. Council Incumbents, Major Challenges |work=The Washington Post |date=August 23, 2004 |page=B1}} and had $42,295 on hand. Gray's campaign theme was that Chavous was out of touch with the ward, rarely attending neighborhood events and traveling out of town too frequently. Sam Bost, president of the influential Far Northeast/Southeast Council, announced in mid August that he would no longer support Chavous, and Gray won endorsements from several key organizations and individuals. Chavous argued that working on legislation consumed most of his time, and pointed to the school voucher program and the extensive charter school network in the city as major accomplishments. By August 22, Gray had raised $38,531 for a total of $52,389, while Chavous had raised $110,199 (and had $42,296 on hand).{{cite news |last=Woodlee |first=Yolanda |title=Barry Filing Incomplete |work=The Washington Post |date=August 26, 2004 |page=B2}} The Chavous campaign received a blow on August 31 when the D.C. Democratic State Committee voted 35-to-3 to endorse Gray in the Ward 7 Democratic primary race. The vote, which ''The Washington Post'' called "an embarrassment" for Chavous, was the first time committee had endorsed a candidate in a primary election.{{cite news |last1=Montgomery |first1=Lori |last2=Woodlee |first2=Yolanda |title=Party Committee Rejects Chavous, Backs Ward 7 Challenger |work=The Washington Post |date=September 1, 2004 |page=B4}} Chavous dismissed the outcome, calling the vote "a sham".{{cite news |last=Nakamura |first=David |title=Chavous Unfazed Party's Rebuff |work=The Washington Post |date=September 2, 2004 |page=B1}} As the primary approached on September 14, the ''Post'' called the election the closest since Chavous defeated Crawford in 1992. Voter sentiment seemed to focus on the 2003–2004 Board of Education reform debate, with voters blaming Chavous for the long debate—which, many said, discouraged the two leading candidates for superintendent to drop out. Gray also hammered Chavous on his support for the federal voucher program, which he claimed took money away from public schools. Chavous argued that he had helped improve the delivery and amount of city services, was critical in winning construction of two new public schools in Ward 7, and that he had brought economic development to the area by shepherding the redevelopment of the Skyland shopping mall.{{cite news |last1=Montgomery |first1=Lori |last2=Woodlee |first2=Yolanda |title=Barry In, 3 D.C. Council Incumbents Out |work=The Washington Post |date=September 15, 2004 |page=A1}} By the end of the primary, Chavous had raised $138,849 in contributions.{{cite news |last1=Woodlee |first1=Yolanda |last2=Strauss |first2=Valerie |title=Chavous Camp Missed Filings, Wrote Checks Without Funds |work=The Washington Post |date=December 10, 2004 |page=B1}} Chavous lost his bid for reelection after losing the September 14, 2004, Democratic primary to Gray, 50 percent to 34 percent. David Nakamura, reporter for ''The Washington Post'', said that voters were unhappy with city schools, which had not improved despite the reforms Chavous took credit for.{{cite news |last=Nakamura |first=David |title=East of the Anacostia, Anger Is Power |work=The Washington Post |date=September 15, 2004 |page=A12}} The D.C. Office of Campaign Finance began an investigation into the 2004 Chavous Democratic primary campaign. ''The Washington Post'' reported that the Chavous campaign failed to file financial reports for October and November and paid three invoices totaling $9,000 when the campaign did not have [[Non-sufficient funds|funds to cover the checks]]. A creditor then filed a complaint with the D.C. police. The Office of Campaign Finance scheduled a hearing on the alleged campaign violations in November 2004, but Chavous did not appear. In an interview with the ''Post'', Chavous blamed a bank error and his campaign treasurer for the problems. Chavous personally gave one creditor a $5,000 [[cashier's check]] to cover a radio ad purchase, and his campaign's field coordinator was paid using $2,000 of Chavous' personal funds and $1,000 of the campaign's funds. ==National education reform advocacy== In 2004, Chavous authored the book ''Serving Our Children: Charter Schools and the Reform of American Public Education''.{{cite news |last=Tonn |first=Jessica L. |title=People in the News: Kevin P. Chavous |work=Education Week |date=February 15, 2005 |accessdate=November 3, 2015 |url=http://www.edweek.org/ew/articles/2005/02/16/23people-2.h24.html}} The following year, he was named a Distinguished Fellow with the [[Center for Education Reform]]. Chavous served on the education policy committee of [[Barack Obama]]'s 2008 reelection campaign.{{cite news |last=Chavous |first=Kevin P. |title=Gainful Employment |work=The Hill |date=May 31, 2011 |accessdate=November 3, 2015 |url=http://thehill.com/blogs/congress-blog/education/163941-gainful-employment-}} The same year, he co-founded and was named chairman of the board of directors of [[Democrats for Education Reform]] (DFER), a [[political action committee]] which supports Democratic candidates for office who support school vouchers,{{cite book |title=Who's Who in Black Washington, D.C. |location=Columbus, Ohio |publisher=Who's Who Publishing Company |date=2009 |page=206 |postscript=none}}; {{cite news |last=Klein |first=Alyson |title=Democratic Education PAC Hopes for Its Moment Under Obama |work=Education Week |date=November 26, 2008 |accessdate=November 3, 2015 |url=http://www.edweek.org/ew/articles/2008/12/03/14dfer.h28.html}} and with DFER founded the Education Equality Project.{{cite web|title=Kevin P. Chavous |website=State Policy Network |date=May 27, 2010 |accessdate=November 3, 2015 |url=https://www.spn.org/publications/kevin-p-chavous- |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150916173842/http://www.spn.org/publications/kevin-p-chavous- |archivedate=September 16, 2015 |df= }} He also co-founded in 2008 the nonprofit organization Serving Our Children, which provides grants to teachers for the purchase of classroom supplies. He was also named that year to the board of directors of the [[Black Alliance for Educational Options]], an educational reform group promoting school vouchers and charter schools. He became the group's chairman in 2010.{{cite web |title=Kevin P. Chavous Sworn In as the New BAEO Board Chair |website=Black Alliance for Educational Options |date=March 9, 2010 |accessdate=November 3, 2015 |url=http://scoter2.baeo.org/downloads.php?download_id=85&filename=chavous%20new%20chair.pdf}} In 2010, Chavous was part of the team formed by [[Bobby Jindal]], [[List of Governors of Louisiana|Governor of Louisiana]], to develop a school voucher program for [[New Orleans]]. The group successfully lobbied the [[Louisiana State Legislature]] for passage of the program. Chavous joined the board of directors of the [[American Federation for Children]] and the [[Alliance for School Choice]] about 2011, organizations co-founded by Republican politician [[Betsy DeVos]].{{cite web |last=Tabachnick |first=Rachel |title=Talk to Action: Voucher Advocate Betsy DeVos, Right-Wing Think Tanks Behind Koch-Style Attack on PA Public Schools |website=K12 News Network |date=April 26, 2011 |accessdate=November 3, 2015 |url=http://thewire.k12newsnetwork.com/2011/04/26/from-guest-blogger-rachel-tabachnick-talk-to-action-voucher-advocate-betsy-devos-right-wing-think-tanks-behind-koch-style-attack-on-pa-public-schools-section-2/}} In 2012, he served as executive counsel for the American Federation for Children.{{cite news |last=Chavous |first=Kevin P. |title=The Obama-Romney Education Summit Agenda |work=The Huffington Post |date=August 30, 2012 |accessdate=November 3, 2015 |url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/kevin-p-chavous/politics-education-reform-_b_1841599.html}} Also in 2012, Chavous served as a lobbyist for [[Intralot]], the contractor which provided lottery services to the [[D.C. Lottery]].{{cite news |last=Anderson |first=Jeffrey |title=Memo Tells of Politics, Power for D.C. Lottery Deal |work=The Washington Times |date=September 4, 2012 |accessdate=November 5, 2015 |url=http://www.washingtontimes.com/news/2012/sep/4/memo-tells-of-politics-power-for-lottery-deal/?page=all}} ==Personal life== In 1982, Chavous married attorney and law school classmate Beverly Bass. The couple divorced in 2009.{{citation needed|date=November 2015}} They have two sons, Kevin (born 1984) and Eric (born 1990). ==Electoral history== ===1992=== {{Election box begin no change | title = [[Council of the District of Columbia]], [[Neighborhoods in Washington, D.C.#Ward 7|Ward 7]], [[Democratic Party (United States)|Democratic]] [[primary election]], 1992"[http://search.proquest.com/docview/307550559/ D.C. Primary Results: D.C. Council]". ''The Washington Post''. September 16, 1992. }} {{election box winning candidate with party link no change | candidate = Kevin P. Chavous | party = Democratic Party (United States) | votes = 4,816 | percentage = 42 }} {{election box candidate with party link no change | candidate = [[H. R. revision.text:
{{use mdy dates|date=October 2015}} {{use American English|date=October 2015}} {{Infobox football official | name = Mark Geiger | image = Mark Geiger.jpg | caption = Geiger in 2018 | fullname = Mark William Geiger | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|mf=yes|1974|8|25}} | birth_place = [[Beachwood, New Jersey]], U.S. | death_date = | death_place = | otheroccupation = Mathematics teacher | years1 = 2002–2004 | league1 = [[A-League (1995–2004)|A-League]] | role1 = [[Referee (association football)|Referee]] | years2 = 2004–present | league2 = [[Major League Soccer|MLS]] | role2 = [[Referee (association football)|Referee]] | years3 = 2011–present | league3 = [[North American Soccer League|NASL]] | role3 = [[Referee (association football)|Referee]] | internationalyears1 = 2008–present | confederation1 = [[FIFA International Referees List|FIFA listed]] | internationalrole1 = [[Referee (association football)|Referee]] }}
'''Mark William Geiger''' (born August 25, 1974) is an American [[Association football|soccer]] [[Referee (association football)|referee]] who officiates at domestic level in [[Major League Soccer]] (MLS) and who has been on the [[FIFA International Referees List]] since 2008. He is also a member of the [[Professional Referee Organization]] (PRO). At the international level, Geiger has refereed the [[Football at the 2012 Summer Olympics|2012 Olympics]]; at the [[2013 CONCACAF Gold Cup|2013]] and [[2015 CONCACAF Gold Cup]]s; and at the [[2014 FIFA World Cup|2014]] and [[2018 FIFA World Cup]]s. At the 2014 World Cup, he became the first referee from the United States to officiate a knockout match at a World Cup tournament. Before becoming a full-time referee, Geiger was a high school [[mathematics]] teacher.
==Refereeing career== Geiger first took up refereeing in 1988. He became a [[United States Soccer Federation]] National Referee in 2003 and has been officiating in [[Major League Soccer]] since 2004. He has officiated in [[CONCACAF]] tournaments since becoming a [[FIFA]] referee in 2008, and has officiated [[CONCACAF Gold Cup|Gold Cup]] and other international tournaments and fixtures. Geiger was selected for the [[2011 CONCACAF U-20 Championship|CONCACAF U-20 Championship]] in 2011, where he refereed the final.<ref name="concacaf-u20final">{{cite web|url=http://www.concacaf.com/page/CL/NewsDetail/0,,12813~2425158,00.html |title=Geiger to referee U-20 final, CCL Round 2 |publisher=CONCACAF |date=August 19, 2011 |accessdate=October 7, 2015 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120925222919/http://www.concacaf.com/page/CL/NewsDetail/0%2C%2C12813~2425158%2C00.html |archivedate=September 25, 2012 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref>
Geiger officiated at the [[2011 FIFA U-20 World Cup]] in [[Colombia]].<ref name="us-soccer-2011u20wc">{{cite web | url=http://www.ussoccer.com/stories/2014/03/17/13/03/mark-geiger-and-mark-hurd-invited-to-referee-at-2011-fifa-u20-world-cup | title=U.S. Soccer Referee Mark Geiger and Assistant Referee Mark Hurd to Participate at the 2011 FIFA U-20 World Cup in Colombia | publisher=U.S. Soccer | date=May 16, 2011 | accessdate=October 7, 2015}}</ref> He officiated the [[2011 FIFA U-20 World Cup#Group E|Group E]] game between eventual tournament champions [[Brazil national under-20 football team|Brazil]] and [[Austria national under-20 football team|Austria]] at [[Estadio Metropolitano Roberto Meléndez]] in Barranquilla.<ref name="fifa-brazilvsaustria">{{cite web | url=https://www.fifa.com/u20worldcup/matches/round=255641/match=300145877/report.html | title=Match Report - Brazil 3-0 Austria | publisher=FIFA | accessdate=October 10, 2015}}</ref> He then took charge of the [[2011 FIFA U-20 World Cup#Group B|Group B]] game between [[Uruguay national under-20 football team|Uruguay]] and [[Cameroon national under-20 football team|Cameroon]] at [[Estadio El Campín]] in [[Bogotá]].<ref name="fifa-uruguayvscameroon">{{cite web | url=https://www.fifa.com/u20worldcup/matches/round=255641/match=300145861/report.html| title=Match Report - Uruguay 0-1 Cameroon | publisher=FIFA | accessdate=October 10, 2015}}</ref> He was appointed to the [[2011 FIFA U-20 World Cup#Round of 16|Round of 16]] match between [[Spain national under-20 football team|Spain]] and [[South Korea national under-20 football team|South Korea]] at [[Estadio Palogrande]] in Manizales.<ref name="fifa-spainvskorea">{{cite web | url=https://www.fifa.com/u20worldcup/matches/round=255639/match=300145889/report.html| title=Match Report - Spain 0-0 Korea Republic| publisher=FIFA | accessdate=October 10, 2015}}</ref> Finally, he refereed the [[2011 FIFA U-20 World Cup#Final|Final]] with American Assistant Referee Sean Hurd and Canadian Assistant Referee Joe Fletcher, between [[Brazil national under-20 football team|Brazil]] and [[Portugal national under-20 football team|Portugal]] at [[Estadio El Campín]] in Bogotá.<ref name="fifa-brazilvsportugal">{{cite web | url=https://www.fifa.com/u20worldcup/matches/round=255635/match=300145903/report.html| title=Match Report - Brazil 3-2 Portugual| publisher=FIFA | accessdate=October 10, 2015}}</ref> This is the first time a referee from the [[United States]] has ever officiated a major men's tournament final.<ref name="psra-u20final">{{cite web | url=http://www.refereeassociation.net/articles.php?ID=83 | title=Geiger, Hurd and Fletcher to Officiate FIFA U20 World Cup Final | publisher=Professional Soccer Referees Association | accessdate=October 10, 2015 | deadurl=yes | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150723080617/http://www.refereeassociation.net/articles.php?ID=83 | archivedate=July 23, 2015 | df=mdy-all }}</ref>
Geiger was selected as the Major League Soccer referee of the year for the 2011 season, and then again in 2014.<ref name="mls-refofyear2011">{{cite web | url=http://www.mlssoccer.com/post/2011/11/10/mls-veteran-geiger-named-referee-year | title=MLS veteran Geiger named Referee of the Year | publisher=Major League Soccer | date=November 10, 2011 | accessdate=October 7, 2015}}</ref><ref name="mls-refofyear2014">{{cite web | url=http://www.mlssoccer.com/news/article/2014/11/25/mark-geiger-named-mls-referee-year-paul-scott-voted-assistant-referee-year | title=Mark Geiger named MLS Referee of the Year; Paul Scott voted Assistant Referee of the Year | publisher=Major League Soccer | date=November 25, 2014 | accessdate=October 7, 2015 | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150221163408/http://www.mlssoccer.com/news/article/2014/11/25/mark-geiger-named-mls-referee-year-paul-scott-voted-assistant-referee-year | archivedate=February 21, 2015}}</ref>
In 2012, Geiger was selected as one of 16 referees to officiate at the [[2012 Summer Olympics]] in London. Geiger took charge of the Group D [[Football at the 2012 Summer Olympics – Men's tournament – Group D#Spain vs Japan|match between Spain vs. Japan]]<ref name="fifa-spainvjapan">{{cite web|url=https://www.fifa.com/mensolympic/matches/round=256009/match=300197675/index.html |title=Matchcast - Spain 0:1 Japan |publisher=FIFA |accessdate=October 7, 2015 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130524035202/http://www.fifa.com/mensolympic/matches/round%3D256009/match%3D300197675/index.html |archivedate=May 24, 2013 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref> and the [[Football at the 2012 Summer Olympics – Men's tournament – Knockout stage#Japan vs Egypt|quarterfinal between Japan vs. Egypt]]. In 2013, Geiger was an official at the [[2013 CONCACAF Gold Cup]].<ref name="PRO Referee Roster">{{cite web|title=PRO Referee Roster|url=http://www.proreferees.com/roster-referees.php|publisher=Professional Referee Organization|accessdate=October 6, 2013|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130603223128/http://www.proreferees.com/roster-referees.php|archivedate=June 3, 2013|df=mdy-all}}</ref>
Geiger was selected as [[CONCACAF|CONCACAF's]] representative referee for the [[2013 FIFA Club World Cup|2013 Club World Cup]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.fifa.com/mm/document/tournament/competition/02/22/25/89/fcwc2013matchofficials_neutral.pdf|title=FCWC 2013 Appointments of Match Officials|publisher=FIFA}}</ref>
===2014 FIFA World Cup=== Geiger was one of 25 referees appointed for the [[2014 FIFA World Cup]] in Brazil.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.fifa.com/worldcup/media/newsid=2261111/index.html|title=Referee trios and support duos appointed for 2014 FIFA World Cup™|publisher=FIFA|date=January 15, 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.fifa.com/mm/document/tournament/competition/02/26/13/55/2014fwcrefereesselected_neutral.pdf|title=Referees & Assistant referees for the 2014 FIFA World Cup™|publisher=FIFA|date=January 14, 2014}}</ref> Geiger described the assignment to the World Cup as "an immensely proud moment".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.proreferees.com/news--mark-geiger-excited-to-fulfil-world-cup-dream.php|title=Mark Geiger excited to fulfil World Cup dream|publisher=Professional Referee Organization|date=January 20, 2014}}</ref> Geiger officiated the 2014 World Cup [[2014 FIFA World Cup Group C|Group C]] match between [[Colombia national football team|Colombia]] and [[Greece national football team|Greece]] at the [[Estadio Mineirão]] in Belo Horizonte;<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.fifa.com/worldcup/news/y=2014/m=6/news=referee-designations-for-matches-5-8-2368666.html |publisher=FIFA|date=June 12, 2014|title=Referee designations for matches 5-8|accessdate=October 7, 2015}}</ref> the 2014 World Cup [[2014 FIFA World Cup Group B|Group B]] match between [[Chile national football team|Chile]] and [[Spain national football team|Spain]] at the [[Estádio do Maracanã|Maracanã Stadium]] in Rio de Janeiro;<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.fifa.com/worldcup/matches/round=255931/match=300186498/index.html#nosticky |title=2014 Fifa World Cup Brazil Match Result: Spain v Chile|publisher=FIFA}}</ref> and the 2014 World Cup [[2014 FIFA World Cup knockout stage|Round of 16]] match between [[France national football team|France]] and [[Nigeria national football team|Nigeria]] at the [[Estádio Nacional Mané Garrincha|Estádio Nacional]] in Brasilia, the first American to referee in the knockout round of a FIFA World Cup.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.proreferees.com/news-pro-2014-world-cup-assignments.php|title=PRO 2014 World Cup assignments|publisher=Professional Referee Organization|date=June 28, 2014}}</ref>
===2017 FIFA Confederations Cup=== Geiger was selected to officiate the [[2017 FIFA Confederations Cup]] in [[Russia]]. In the Group Stage, Geiger officiated the [[2017 FIFA Confederations Cup Group B|Group B]] match between [[Australia national soccer team|Australia]] and [[Germany national football team|Germany]] in [[Sochi, Russia|Sochi]] as well as the [[2017 FIFA Confederations Cup Group A|Group A]] match between [[New Zealand national football team|New Zealand]] and [[Portugal national football team|Portugal]] in [[Saint Petersburg, Russia|Saint Petersburg]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Australia-Germany Match Overview|url=https://www.fifa.com/confederationscup/matches/round=274633/match=300334890/index.html#nosticky|publisher=FIFA|date=June 19, 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=New Zealand-Portugal Match Overview|url=https://www.fifa.com/confederationscup/matches/round=274633/match=300334887/index.html#nosticky|publisher=FIFA|date=June 24, 2017}}</ref>
===2018 FIFA World Cup=== Geiger was one of 36 referees selected for the [[2018 FIFA World Cup]], working with a North American crew of [[Joe_Fletcher_(referee)|Joe Fletcher]] from Canada and Frank Anderson from USA. <ref>https://www.fifa.com/worldcup/news/36-referees-and-63-assistant-referees-appointed-as-russia-2018-match-officials</ref> Geiger served as referee on three matches at the tournament and was VAR on five matches.
Geiger’s first assignment was the second group stage match of Group B between [[2018_FIFA_World_Cup_Group_B#Portugal_vs_Morocco|Portugal and Morocco]]. Geiger worked as the [[Video_assistant_referee|VAR]] In the match between [[2018_FIFA_World_Cup_Group_C#Denmark_vs_Australia|Denmark and Australia]]. During the match he advised the referee, [[Antonio Mateu Lahoz]], to review a possible handball in the penalty area. After review, Lahoz awarded a penalty kick that allowed the Socceroos to score and secure a 1-1 draw.<ref>http://www.espn.com/soccer/report?gameId=498181</ref> He subsequently worked as VAR for the Group D match between Argentina and Iceland, the Group E match featuring Belgium and Tunisia and the Round of 16 contest between Uruguay and Portugal before his final assignment in the tournament’s Third Place match.
Geiger then officiated the Group F third match between [[2018_FIFA_World_Cup_Group_F#South_Korea_vs_Germany|South Korea and Germany]].<ref>http://www.sportingnews.com/soccer/news/world-cup-2018-south-korea-germany-marco-reus-timo-werner-laud-son-heung-min/x01b4wpdza3n1r8b8hpr2inyg</ref> South Korea defeated Germany 2-0, but neither team advanced since Sweden defeated Mexico.<ref>https://www.fifa.com/worldcup/matches/match/300331532/#match-summary</ref> He then officiated at the Round of 16 game between [[2018_FIFA_World_Cup_knockout_stage#Colombia_vs_England|Colombia and England]]. England advanced on penalties after a 1-1 draw. Geiger was selected as one of the final 12 referees on the shortlist to officiate the final or third place play-off match, <ref>{{Cite web |title=PRO referee Mark Geiger among those selected for final phase of World Cup |url=https://www.mlssoccer.com/post/2018/07/10/pro-referee-mark-geiger-among-those-selected-final-phase-world-cup |work=MLS Soccer |date=10 July 2018 |accessdate=2018-07-11}}</ref> and was ultimately selected to be VAR on the 3rd place match between [[2018_FIFA_World_Cup_knockout_stage#Third_place_play-off|Belgium and England]].<ref>https://twitter.com/fifamedia/status/1017489193906425865</ref>
==FIFA World Cup== [[File:FWC 2018 - Round of 16 - COL v ENG - Photo 088.jpg|thumb|right|Mark Geiger and goalkeepers [[Jordan Pickford]] from England and [[David Ospina]] from Colombia before the penalty shootout in the Round of 16]] {| class="wikitable" style="margin:1em auto 1em auto; text-align:center; font-size:85%;" ! colspan="4" | 2014 FIFA World Cup – Brazil |- ! Date !! Match !! Venue !! Round |- | June 14, 2014 || {{fb|COL}} – {{fb|GRE}} || [[Mineirão|Belo Horizonte]] || Group stage |- | June 18, 2014 || {{fb|ESP}} – {{fb|CHI}} || [[Maracanã Stadium|Rio de Janeiro]] || Group stage |- | June 30, 2014 || {{fb|FRA}} – {{fb|NGA}} || [[Estádio Nacional Mané Garrincha|Brasília]] || Round of 16 |- ! colspan="4" | 2018 FIFA World Cup – Russia |- ! Date !! Match !! Venue !! Round |- | June 20, 2018 || {{fb|POR}} – {{fb|MAR}} || [[Luzhniki Stadium|Moscow]] || Group stage |- | June 27, 2018 || {{fb|KOR}} – {{fb|GER}} || [[Kazan Arena|Kazan]] || Group stage |- | July 3, 2018 || {{fb|COL}} – {{fb|ENG}} || [[Otkritie Arena|Moscow]] || Round of 16 |- |}
==Personal life== Geiger was born on August 25, 1974 and grew up in [[Beachwood, New Jersey]]. After studying teaching at [[Trenton State College]], he became a mathematics teacher at [[Lacey Township High School]] in [[Lanoka Harbor, New Jersey]], a role that he gave up to become a full-time referee. While at Lacey Township High School, Geiger was among 103 recipients of the Presidential Award for Excellence in Math and Science Teaching in 2010.<ref name="fifa-2014prospectiverefs">{{cite web | url=https://www.fifa.com/mm/document/tournament/competition/02/04/76/97/open_list_prospective_referees__assistants_2014fwcrefereesproject2012_march2013.pdf | title=Open list of prospective referees & assistant referees for the 2014 FIFA World Cup | publisher=FIFA | accessdate=October 6, 2015}}</ref><ref name="whitehouse">{{cite press release | url=https://www.whitehouse.gov/the-press-office/presidential-math-and-science-teachers-award-release | title=Presidential Math and Science Teachers Award Release | publisher=The White House | date=June 7, 2010 | accessdate=October 6, 2015 | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150723125224/https://www.whitehouse.gov/the-press-office/presidential-math-and-science-teachers-award-release | archivedate=July 23, 2015}}</ref><ref name="washpost-refereeprofile">{{cite news | url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/sports/dcunited/retired-math-teacher-mark-geiger-is-the-only-american-selected-to-referee-the-world-cup/2014/06/10/3a544ad6-efda-11e3-bf76-447a5df6411f_story.html | title=Retired math teacher Mark Geiger is the only American selected to referee the World Cup | work=The Washington Post | date=June 10, 2014 | accessdate=October 6, 2015 | author=Day, Timothy D.}}</ref>
==Honors== *[[MLS Referee of the Year Award|MLS Referee of the Year]]: [[2011 Major League Soccer season|2011]], [[2014 Major League Soccer season|2014]] * Morgan J. Hellebuyck North American Officials Award 2006
==References== {{reflist|30em}}
==External links== * [http://www.proreferees.com/roster-mark-geiger.php Profile] at Professional Referee Organization * [http://worldreferee.com/site/copy.php?linkType=referee&contextType=bio&linkID=1646 Profile] at worldreferee.com * [https://int.soccerway.com/referees/mark-geiger/82588/ Profile] at int.soccerway.com
