revision.text:
{{infobox writer |name= Ned Balbo |image=Ned Balbo.jpg |imagesize= |alt= |caption=Ned Balbo attending the [[West Chester University Poetry Conference]] |pseudonym= |birth_date= {{Birth date and age|1959|11|19}} |birth_place= |death_date= |death_place= |resting_place= |occupation= [[poet]], [[essayist]], and [[professor]] |language= |nationality= American |ethnicity= |citizenship= |education= |alma_mater= Brentwood High School '77
Vassar College '81, A.B.
Johns Hopkins University '86, M.A.
University of Iowa '89, M.F.A. |period= |genre= poetry, essay |subject= |movement= |notableworks= |spouse= [[Jane Satterfield]] |partner= |children= |relatives= |influences= |influenced= |awards= [[Richard Wilbur Award]], 2018 [[National Endowment for the Arts]] Literature in Translation Fellowship, 2017 [[Willis Barnstone Translation Prize]] co-winner, 2013 [[Poets' Prize]], 2012 [[Donald Justice Poetry Prize]], 2010 ''[[Foreword Reviews|ForeWord Magazine's]]'' Book of the Year Gold Medal, 2005{{cite web |title=2005 Foreword INDIES Winners in Poetry (Adult Nonfiction) |url=https://www.forewordreviews.com/awards/winners/2005/poetry/ |publisher=[[Foreword Reviews]] |language=en}} Ernest Sandeen Prize in Poetry, 2005 Robert Frost Foundation Poetry Award, 2003 John Guyon Prize in Literary Nonfiction, 2002 [[Towson University]] Prize for Literature"[http://www.montgomerycollege.edu/news/print/News_Archives/news08190501.html Montgomery College to Host Four Readings by Award-Winning Authors: “Books and Ideas” Series Features Pietrzyk, Morris and Poets Satterfield, Balbo]." ''Montgomery College.'' August 19, 2005 co-winner, 1998 |signature= |signature_alt= |website= |portaldisp= }} '''Ned Balbo''' (born November 19, 1959, [[Mineola, New York]])"[http://authorities.loc.gov/cgi-bin/Pwebrecon.cgi?AuthRecID=424843&v1=1&HC=1&SEQ=20100926201706&PID=bSRWteWpKwpLr_KVul42qpl-Hu7LT MARC Display]." ''Library of Congress Authorities''. The Library of Congress. is an American [[poet]], [[translator]], and [[essayist]]. ==Life== Ned Balbo grew up on [[Long Island, New York]]. He was raised by Betty and Carmine Balbo, his birth mother's half-sister and her husband, who he believed were his parents.{{cite web|url=http://islandsofjoy.blogspot.com/search?q=ned+balbo|title=Islands of Joy|website=islandsofjoy.blogspot.com}} At thirteen Balbo learned he was adopted.{{cite web|url=http://poetsonadoption.blogspot.com/2011/03/ned-balbo.html|title=POETS ON ADOPTION: NED BALBO|first=|last=Eileen|date=18 March 2011|publisher=}} This background informs his creative work.{{cite web|url=http://www.versewisconsin.org/Issue105/reviews105/balbo.html|title=Verse Wisconsin 105- Review of Ned Balbo|website=www.versewisconsin.org}} Balbo graduated from [[Brentwood High School (Brentwood, New York)|Brentwood High School]] in 1977.{{cite web|url=https://www.facebook.com/ned.balbo|title=Ned Balbo|website=www.facebook.com}} He earned his [[Bachelor of Arts]] at [[Vassar College]] in 1981, his [[Master of Arts]] at [[Johns Hopkins University]] in 1986, and his [[Master of Fine Arts]] at the [[Iowa Writers' Workshop]] in 1989.[http://www.catalogue.loyola.edu/catalogues/current/archive/grc9900.pdf Graduate Programs]. Loyola College in Maryland Balbo taught poetry and prose at [[Loyola University Maryland]] from 1990 to 2014.{{Cite web |url=http://cheausa.org/poet-versus-party-line-dismissal-ned-balbo/# |title=Archived copy |access-date=2015-09-09 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150125135438/http://cheausa.org/poet-versus-party-line-dismissal-ned-balbo/# |archive-date=2015-01-25 |dead-url=yes |df= }} He was also a visiting faculty member in the MFA program in Creative Writing and Environment at [[Iowa State University]].{{cite web|url=https://www.wcupa.edu/arts-humanities/poetry/documents/Poet_Bios.pdf |title=Bio |website=www.wcupa.edu |format=PDF}} He is married to poet-essayist [[Jane Satterfield]]. ==Poetry and style== According to Lisa Vihos in ''Verse Wisconsin'', "Balbo...gives shape and heft to the formless, fleeting past {{mdash}} both historical and personal {{mdash}} through his rich language."{{cite web|url=http://www.versewisconsin.org/Issue103/reviews103/balbo_vihos.html|title=Verse Wisconsin 103-Balbo Review|website=www.versewisconsin.org}} In reviewing ''The Trials of Edgar Poe and Other Poems'' for ''JMWW'', Patricia Valdata observes that Balbo's work "raises difficult questions about home, about the relationship of parent to child, about a society's responsibility to its poor."{{cite web|url=http://www.jmww.150m.com/Balborev2.html|title=Free Web Hosting, Free Website Builder, Make a Website|website=www.jmww.150m.com}} Writing in ''Studio'', Lucas Jacob notes that in ''The Trials of Edgar Poe and Other Poems'', "Balbo...reminds us of the grace we find in our time with each other on this 'island' of life on Earth."{{cite web|url=http://studiojournal.ca/vol-5-1-2011/reviews/jacob/index.html|title=STUDIO Volume 5 Number 1, 2011 - Review|website=studiojournal.ca}} [[Lesley Wheeler]], writing on-line in [[Kenyon Review]], asserts that "Balbo’s complicated sense of place and his poetic resourcefulness make [''Upcycling Paumanok''] worth your time, but what impresses me most are the extended narrative lyrics, the first of which appears several pages in. Balbo’s deftness at balancing story and music is often breathtaking."{{cite web|url=https://www.kenyonreview.org/reviews/micro-reviews-nov-2016/|title=November Micro-Reviews - The Kenyon Review|publisher=}} Balbo has written in a variety of [[New Formalism|forms]], including [[blank verse]], sonnets, villanelles, sestinas, and nonce forms, as well as [[free verse]]. His poetic influences include Ai, Elizabeth Bishop, Louise Bogan, Robert Frost, Randall Jarrell, Denis Johnson, Weldon Kees, and others.{{cite web|url=https://www.facebook.com/pages/Ned-Balbo/265838986763467?sk=info|title=Ned Balbo: poet, translator, essayist|website=www.facebook.com}} ==Awards== In addition to book awards, Balbo received a 2017 [[National Endowment for the Arts]] Literature in Translation Fellowship.{{cite web|url=https://www.arts.gov/sites/default/files/FY17-NEA-Literature-Translation-Fellowship-Recipients.pdf |title=Fellowship recipients |website=www.arts.gov |format=PDF}} He is the recipient of three Maryland Arts Council Individual Artist Awards in poetry and the Robert Frost Foundation Poetry Award.Lori A. May "[http://poetsquarterly.yolasite.com/spring10_nedbalbo.php An interview with Ned Balbo]." ''Poets' Quarterly'' Issue 3. April 2010. He received the John Guyon Literary Nonfiction Prize for the essay "Walt Whitman's Finches: on discretion and disclosure in autobiography and adoption," published in the literary journal ''Crab Orchard Review'' in 2002.{{Cite web |url=http://craborchardreview.siuc.edu/guyon1.html# |title=Archived copy |access-date=2010-10-08 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100326211616/http://craborchardreview.siuc.edu/guyon1.html# |archive-date=2010-03-26 |dead-url=yes |df= }} "My Father's Music," an essay on adoption, ethnicity, and popular culture, and a finalist for the Pirate's Alley William Faulkner Society's Gold Medal in the Essay,{{cite web |url=http://www.wordsandmusic.org/2005FaulknerWinners.html |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2009-12-01 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100107212518/http://wordsandmusic.org/2005FaulknerWinners.html |archivedate=2010-01-07 |df= }} appears in ''Our Roots Are Deep with Passion: ''Creative Nonfiction'' Collects New Essays by Italian American Writers'' (Other Press, 2006).{{cite web|url=https://www.forewordreviews.com/reviews/our-roots-are-deep-with-passion/|title=Review of Our Roots Are Deep with Passion|publisher=}} An Italian version of this essay (Carla Antonucci, translator) appeared as “La Musica di mio padre” in ''Padri: Tre memoir italo americani,'' edited by Anna Maria Crispino (Iacobelli: Rome, 2009).{{cite web|url=http://www.bottegascriptamanent.it/?modulo=Articolo&id=831|title=Bottega Scriptamanent|website=www.bottegascriptamanent.it}} Balbo has also been a Walter E. Dakin [[fellow]] at the [[Sewanee Writers' Conference]] and several times a [[fellow]] in poetry at the [[Virginia Center for the Creative Arts]] ."[http://www.redroom.com/author/ned-balbo/bio Ned Balbo's Biography]." ''Ned Balbo: Poet and Essayist''. Red Room. Accessed: Sept. 26, 2010 ==Bibliography== ===Books=== *2018 — ''3 Nights of the Perseids'' (University of Evansville Press; winner of [[Richard Wilbur Award]])https://www.evansville.edu/majors/creativewriting/downloads/wilbur.pdf *2016 — ''Upcycling Paumanok'' (Measure Press){{cite web|url=http://www.measurepress.com/measure/index.php/catalog/books/upcycling-paumanok/|title=Measure Press :: Upcycling Paumanok|website=www.measurepress.com}} *2010 — ''The Trials of Edgar Poe and Other Poems'' (Story Line Press; winner of [[Donald Justice Poetry Prize]] and 2012 [[Poets' Prize]]){{cite web|url=https://www.facebook.com/pages/Ned-Balbo/265838986763467|title=Ned Balbo: poet, translator, essayist|website=www.facebook.com}} *2005 — ''Lives of the Sleepers'' (University of Notre Dame Press; winner of Ernest Sandeen Prize and ''[[Foreword Reviews|ForeWord Magazine's]]'' Book of the Year Award, Gold Medal in Poetry)http://undpress.nd.edu/book/P01015 *1998 — ''Galileo’s Banquet'' ([[Washington Writers' Publishing House]]; shared Towson University Prize for Literature with ''God's Long Summer''{{cite web|url=http://press.princeton.edu/titles/8651.html|title=God's Long Summer|website=Princeton University Press}} by Charles Marsh) ===Chapbook=== *2009 — ''Something Must Happen'' (Finishing Line Press) ===Essays=== *2006 — “My Father’s Music.” ''Our Roots Are Deep with Passion:'' Creative Nonfiction ''collects new essays by Italian-American writers''. Eds. [[Lee Gutkind]] and [[Joanna Clapps Herman]]. New York: Other Press, 2006: 87-103.{{cite web|url=https://www.creativenonfiction.org/issue/30|title=Issue 30 - Creative Nonfiction|website=www.creativenonfiction.org}} *2003 — “Paul Is Dead, and We’re All Listening: Rumor and Revelation, 1969.” Spec. nonfiction issue of ''JMWW'' (2011).{{cite web|url=http://jmww.150m.com/Balbo.html|title=Free Web Hosting, Free Website Builder, Make a Website|website=jmww.150m.com}} [Originally appeared in ''Die Cast Garden'' 2 (2003).] *2002 — “Walt Whitman’s Finches: of discretion and disclosure in autobiography and adoption.” ''Crab Orchard Review'' 8.1 (2002): 180-95. ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== *"[http://islandsofjoy.blogspot.com/search?q=ned+balbo Interview]" with Ned Balbo, conducted by Sørina Higgins. *"[http://poems.com/poem.php?date=17403 Stray Crow]" by Ned Balbo - Poetry Daily. *"[http://www.americanlifeinpoetry.org/columns/271.html Fire Victim]" by Ned Balbo - American Life in Poetry, selected by [[Ted Kooser]], [[U.S. Poet Laureate]]. *"[https://www.poetryfoundation.org/poems/57779/the-sugar-thief The Sugar Thief]" by Ned Balbo - Poetry Foundation. *"[https://www.newcriterion.com/issues/2016/9/the-underground-tour The Underground Tour]" by Ned Balbo - The New Criterion. *"[http://www.versedaily.org/2017/holywarsforus.shtml Holy Wars for Us]" by Ned Balbo - Verse Daily. *"[http://www.versedaily.org/2005/aboutnedbalbolots.shtml Desire: A Bestiary]" by Ned Balbo - Verse Daily. *"[http://www.depoetry.com/poets/201701prince/03-balbo-ned.html Musicology]" by Ned Balbo - Delaware Poetry Review. *"[http://www.studiojournal.ca/v04n01/studio2e.html Four Poems]" by Ned Balbo - Studio Journal. *"[https://archive.today/20121220032556/http://frostfoundation.home.comcast.net/~frostfoundation/wsb/html/frostnotes1215/balbo.htm Aristaeus Forgiven]" by Ned Balbo - Frost Notes, [[Robert Frost]] Foundation. *"[http://writersalmanac.publicradio.org/author.php?auth_id=2048 Chesterfield]" by Ned Balbo - The Writer's Almanac, selected by [[Garrison Keillor]]. {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Balbo, Ned}} [[Category:Loyola University Maryland faculty]] [[Category:Vassar College alumni]] [[Category:Johns Hopkins University alumni]] [[Category:Iowa Writers' Workshop alumni]] [[Category:University of Iowa alumni]] [[Category:Poets from New York (state)]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Formalist poets]] [[Category:1959 births]] [[Category:Chapbook writers]] [[Category:People from Long Island]]

revision.comment: Moving from [[Category:Youth organisations based in Nigeria]] to [[Category:Youth organizations based in Nigeria]] using [[c:Help:Cat-a-lot|Cat-a-lot]]
revision.text:
'''New Deal Organization''' is a [[Nigeria]]n [[non-governmental organization]] and latest project of [[Daniel Kanu]], best known for mobilizing the youth in 1998 with his campaign Youth Earnestly Ask for Abacha.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.vanguardngr.com/2014/04/group-lauds-jonathan-confab/ |title=Group lauds Jonathan on confab - Vanguard News |publisher=Vanguardngr.com |date=2014-04-07 |accessdate=2015-09-27}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://newsdiaryonline.com/daniel-kanu-interviewi-new-deal-nigerians |title=Daniel Kanu Interview:'I Have A New Deal For Nigerians' |publisher=Newsdiaryonline.com |date=2014-04-18 |accessdate=2015-09-27}}</ref> In a similar vein to that campaign, this program focuses on the youth of Nigeria and reaches out to youth and parents, offering moral reorientation.<ref name="newsdiaryonline1">{{cite news|url=http://newsdiaryonline.com/kanus-new-deal-begins-moral-re-orientation-campaigns/ |title=Kanu’s New Deal Begins ‘Moral Re-Orientation’ Campaigns |publisher=Newsdiaryonline.com |date=2014-10-15 |accessdate=2015-09-27}}</ref> So far, in 2014 the organization began by targeting schools within the Federal Capital Territory in Abuja such as GSS Apo, GSS Garki, Gss Gwarinpa, GSS Karu and GSS Nyanya.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://newsdiaryonline.com/kanus-new-deal-movement-reaches-gss-apo/ |title=Kanu’s ‘New Deal’ Movement Reaches GSS Apo |publisher=Newsdiaryonline.com |date= |accessdate=2015-09-27}}</ref>
According to News Diary online, the New Deal Organization aims to change the mindset of young people and encourage morality.<ref name="newsdiaryonline1"/> The New Deal combats violence, drug abuse and other societal vices by addressing parents and children and encouraging a synergy to foster beneficial relationships on the basis that good behavior starts in the home.<ref name="allafrica1">{{cite news|author=Daily Trust (Abuja) |url=http://allafrica.com/stories/201404080592.html |title=Nigeria: New Group Emerges to Tackle Youth Indiscipline |publisher=allAfrica.com |date=2014-04-08 |accessdate=2015-09-27}}</ref><ref>http://www.thisdaylive.com/articles/daniel-kanu-and-crimes-prevention-among-the-youths/177022/</ref> To enforce this, the New Deal utilizes a two part plan, called Y.A.C.T. and P.A.C.T., respectively.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.gongnews.net/nigeria-needs-a-new-revolution-to-escape-its-current-crisis-daniel-kanu/ |title=Nigeria needs a new revolution to escape its current crisis – Daniel Kanu |publisher=Gongnews |date=2014-05-25 |accessdate=2015-09-27 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150924022958/http://www.gongnews.net/nigeria-needs-a-new-revolution-to-escape-its-current-crisis-daniel-kanu/ |archivedate=2015-09-24 |df= }}</ref>
== P.A.C.T. ==
P.A.C.T. (Parents Against Crime Together) is one of two parts of the New Deal, and calls for parents to bring back family moral values. As part of P.A.C.T. there are 10 responsibilities for parents, and the call to sign a social contract with their children.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://newsdiaryonline.com/daniel-kanu-interviewi-new-deal-nigerians/ |title=Daniel Kanu Interview:'I Have A New Deal For Nigerians' Newsdiaryonline |publisher=Newsdiaryonline.com |date=2014-04-18 |accessdate=2015-09-27}}</ref>
== Y.A.C.T. ==
Y.A.C.T. (Youths against Crime Together) is the second part of the New Deal, and encourages youth to embrace societal, communal and ethical values. As part of Y.A.C.T., the New deal admonishes children to make a social contract and recommitment to their parents.<ref name="allafrica1"/>
== References ==

revision.comment: [[Mike Ming]] is 6th Oklahoma Secretary of Energy
revision.text:
{{redirect-synonym|OERB|the [[Ontario Educational Resource Bank]]}} {{Infobox Government agency |agency_name = Oklahoma Energy Resources Board |abbreviation = OERB |nativename_a = |nativename_r = |logo = |logo_width = |logo_caption = |seal = |seal_width = 125 px |seal_caption = Great Seal of Oklahoma |formed = January 1, 1993 |preceding1 = |preceding2 = |dissolved = |superseding = |jurisdiction = |headquarters = 3555 NW 58 Street
[[Oklahoma City]], [[Oklahoma]] |employees = 10 unclassified |budget = $15.7 million |minister1_name = [[Mike Ming|C. Michael Ming]] |minister1_pfo = [[Oklahoma Secretary of Energy|Secretary of Energy]] |minister2_name = David House |minister2_pfo = Chair of the Board |chief1_name = Mindy Stitt |chief1_position = Executive Director |chief2_name = |chief2_position = |chief3_name = |chief3_position = |parent_agency = |child1_agency = |child2_agency = |website = [http://www.oerb.com/ Oklahoma Energy Resources Board] |footnotes = }} The '''Oklahoma Energy Resources Board''' (abbreviated '''OERB''') is an [[government agency|agency]] of the state of [[Oklahoma]]. Funded voluntarily by Oklahoma's [[oil]] and [[natural gas]] producers and royalty owners, OERB conducts [[environmental restoration]] of orphaned and abandoned well sites, encourages the wise and efficient use of energy, and promotes energy education.http://oerb.com/about/funding.asp The Board is composed of 21 members. 7 members are appointed by the [[Governor of Oklahoma]], 7 are appointed by the [[President pro tempore of the Oklahoma Senate]], and 7 appointed by the [[Speaker of the Oklahoma House of Representatives]]. All members are either independent oil or natural gas producers or representatives of major oil companies that do business in Oklahoma. The Board, in turn, appoints an Executive Director to serve as the [[chief administrative officer]] of the Board. The current board chairman is David House, president of Jireh Resources, LLC in Tulsa, OK. OERB was created by the [[Oklahoma]] Legislature and energy industry leaders in 1993 during the term of [[Governor of Oklahoma]] [[David Walters]]. ==Mission== The stated missions of the Oklahoma Energy Resources Board are: *to educate Oklahomans about the importance of petroleum (oil and natural gas) in their lives through traditional and non-traditional school curricula, advertising, and public relations *to environmentally restore abandoned well sites to productive land use *to promote environmentally sound production methods and technologies *to research and provide educational activities concerning the petroleum exploration and production industry ==Leadership== OERB is under the leadership of the [[Oklahoma State Cabinet|Secretary of Energy]], the Chair of the Board, and the Executive Director of OERB. Under [[Governor of Oklahoma]] [[Mary Fallin]], C. Michael Ming serves as Secretary, David House serves as the Chairman and Mindy Stitt serves as the Executive Director. ==Environmental restoration== Since its creation in 1993, the OERB has committed $69 million to restore more than 11,800 abandoned and orphaned well sites as part of its [[environmental restoration]] program.[http://oerb.com/restoration/environ-index.asp Well Site Cleanup] It has made restoration progress in 67 of Oklahoma's 77 counties and has a restoration budget of $6 million for the current {{when|date=June 2012}} [[fiscal year]]. Unique is OERB's funding process – though it is funded by a 0.1% assessment on oil and gas sales (not uncommon among similar agencies), it is a '''''voluntary''''' assessment. Any producer or royalty owner may opt out of the program by requesting OERB (between January 1 and March 31 of each year) for a refund of previously paid assessments. OERB states that over 95% of participants remain in the program.{{cite web|url=http://www.oerb.com/Default.aspx?tabid=146|title=OERB|publisher=|accessdate=2 November 2016}} ==Education== Throughout its history, the OERB has reached more than 1 million Oklahoma students with energy curricula, classroom supplies, field trips, college scholarships and presentations. OERB reaches all academic grade levels – from kindergarten through college with its energy education programs, including:http://oerb.com/education/student.asp *The '''OERB Petroleum Scholar Program''' distributes up to $500,000 each year to Oklahoma college students majoring in petroleum-related fields. The deadline for these scholarships is March 1, 2012 and applications can be found at the official. [http://oerb.com/education/student-scholarships.asp OERB Petroleum Scholar] page. *The '''PetroTech Program''' provides training and certification for Oklahomans interested in Geo Tech, Land Tech and Engineering Tech positions within the oil and natural gas industry. Detailed information about the programs can be found at the official [http://www.oerb.com/Default.aspx?tabid=108 Petro Tech page.] The Oklahoma Energy Resources Board created the PetroTech Program to help prepare Oklahomans for careers in the energy industry. A year after its inauguration, the program had accepted more than 400 students and industry employers are now hiring PetroTech graduates.{{cite web|url=http://www.publicbroadcasting.net/kosu/news.newsmain?action=article&ARTICLE_ID=1213057§ionID=1|title=Find Stations and Donate : NPR|publisher=|accessdate=2 November 2016}} *'''Petro Pros''' gives oil and natural gas professionals an opportunity to volunteer their time to visit classrooms and show children the science and business side of the industry. *'''Little Bits''' is a kindergarten through second grade energy curriculum that introduces simple energy terms through games and reading. More than 1,200 teachers have been trained to teach this curriculum. *'''Fossils to Fuel''' is an elementary school energy curriculum with nearly 7,000 teachers trained. *'''Petro Active''' is a middle school energy curriculum with more than 1,600 teachers trained. *'''Core Energy''' is a high school energy curriculum with more than 2,600 teachers trained. *'''Museum Partnerships''' allow the OERB to partner with several museums across the state to enhance energy education curricula and provide free classroom field trips. *The OERB uses '''Safety Videos''' to demonstrate the dangers of playing around well sites. The video entitled, "What's the risk" can be found at OERB's [http://oerb.com/education/student-safety.asp safety page] *'''Well Site Safety Day''' is an annual event at the State Capitol to spread awareness of well site dangers to children, parents and teachers. ==Conservation== Through its '''Conservation Education Program''', the OERB has contributed $1.75 million to help more than 800 Oklahoma families weatherize their homes and save up to 30 percent on their utility bills. In addition to providing weatherization assistance, the OERB provides tips on saving energy and money through advertisements, community events and a [http://oerb.com/conservation/conservation-index.asp website], which includes a “Weatherize Your Home” video demonstration, conservation tips and information on how to apply for home heating assistance. ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== *[http://www.oerb.com/ Official OERB Web site] {{Oklahoma energy agencies}} [[Category:Ecology organizations]] [[Category:State agencies of Oklahoma]] [[Category:Ministries established in 1993]] [[Category:1993 establishments in Oklahoma]] [[Category:Energy education]]

{{Multiple issues |{{Notability|Products|date=July 2011}} {{primary sources|date=July 2011}} }} {{Infobox software | name = openSIS | logo = | screenshot = | caption = | collapsible = | author = | developer = OS4Ed | released = | latest release version = 6.3 | latest release date = 2017.03.03 | latest preview version = | latest preview date = | frequently updated = | programming language = [[PHP]] | operating system = [[Cross-platform]] | platform = | size = | language = Multilingual | status = Active | genre = [[Student Information System]] | license = [[GNU GPL]] v2 | website = [http://www.opensis.com opensis.com] }}
'''openSIS''' is one of several free and open source [[student information system]] available to K-12 and higher education institutions. The solution has been in development for several years and appears to have much of the functionality that long time commercial versions have. The solution is a web-based application developed and maintained by Open Solutions for Education, Inc. (www.os4ed.com).
openSIS is written in [[PHP]] and uses [[MySQL]] to store information. The community edition is released under the terms of the [[GNU General Public License]], is free software, and can be downloaded from the Sourceforge and opensis.com websites. The application is stable, and is in active development cycle with continuing activity in the community forums. openSIS is also offered as a cloud hosted SaaS version at a low cost. Professional and Surge versions are not free but are affordable.
==Product features== According to the company's website, the solutions features these base features:
*Student Photograph *Demographic Information *Contact Information *Parent's and Guardian's Information *Gradebook *Reports/Report Designer *Report Cards *Transcripts *Health Records *Multiple types of Scheduling *Built-in Messaging *Attendance *Parent Portal *User Customizable Preferences *Security *Light Weight IEP *Staff Information *Staff Certification
These are listed as additional modules available in their paid edition or cloud version that is hosted:
*Discipline *Email Messaging *Student Billing *Library Management *On-line Applicant Processing/Admissions *US State Reporting (important for US based schools and districts) *Moodle Integration *SugarCRM Integration
==See also== * [[OpenEMIS]], alternative open source * [[Fedena]], alternative open source * [[SchoolTool]], alternative open source
==Notes== {{reflist}}
== External links == * [http://sourceforge.net/projects/opensis-ce/files/ community development and anonymous download] * [http://www.opensis.com/ Official openSIS site]
[[Category:Learning management systems]] [[Category:Free software projects]] [[Category:Free educational software]] [[Category:School-administration software]]

revision.comment: sp.: [[World Health Organization]], per [[MOS:CONSISTENCY]], proper names use the subject's own spelling (via [[WP:JWB]])
revision.text:
{{Infobox website | name = Pacific Open Learning Health Net | logo = POLHN logo new.jpg | logocaption = | screenshot = | collapsible = | collapsetext = | caption = | url = {{URL|http://polhn.org/}} | commercial = No | type = [[Public]] [[Online education]] | registration = Required | language = English | num_users = more than 30,000 <ref>{{cite web|url=https://polhn.org/about-polhn|title=POLHN website|work=polhn}}</ref> | content license = Copyright of POLHN | owner = Pacific Ministries of Health | author = [[World Health Organization]] | editor = | launch_date = 2003 | current_status = Active | footnotes = }}
'''Pacific Open Learning Health Net''' ('''POLHN''' {{IPAc-en|ˈ|p|ɒ|l|h|ən}}) is a non-profit established in 2003, focused on [[distance education]] for health professionals working in the Pacific. Since 2004, it has provided free online courses for [[continuing professional development]] in a wide range of health and science related disciplines. These include self-directed, [[blended learning]], instructor-led and hybrid courses.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://courses.polhncourses.org/oldmoodle|title=Former Courses|work=polhn}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://courses.polhncourses.org/newmoodle|title=New Courses}}</ref>
The platform runs on a [[free and open-source software]] [[learning management system]]. POLHN works with several universities institutions and Ministries of Health to develop online health related courses guided by [[WHO]] publications and accepted [[standard operating procedure]]. Since 2013, the platform has resembled a typical [[massive open online course]] (MOOC) platform.
==History==
The [[World Health Organization]] ([[WHO]]) and Pacific Ministries of Health established POLHN in 2003 through funding provided by the Government of [[Japan]]. POLHN was established to address the need of [[health professionals]] in the Pacific to access [[continuing professional development]] (CPD) opportunities and up-to-date [[health information]]. POLHN fulfills these needs through an [[e-learning]] network across fourteen [[Pacific Island]] Countries, areas and territories.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.wpro.who.int/southpacific/programmes/pacific_initiatives/polhn/en|title=Overview|work=polhn}}</ref>
==Overview==
POLHN provides access to sponsored and self-paced courses, news, application forms, and links to resources. The website<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.polhn.org|title=POLHN Website|work=polhn}}</ref> is the main gateway to accessing courses, online resources, and health information. The website also contains information about POLHN,<ref>{{cite web|url=https://polhn.org/about-polhn|title=POLHN website - about POLHN|work=polhn}}</ref> information on learning centres,<ref>{{cite web|url=https://polhn.org/learning-centres|title=POLHN website - Learning Centres}}</ref> contact details for POLHN country coordinators,<ref>{{cite web|url=https://polhn.org/team-profiles|title=POLHN website - Meet the Team|work=polhn}}</ref> information on the availability of scholarships,<ref>{{cite web|url=https://polhn.org/scholarships|title=POLHN website-scholarships|work=polhn}}</ref> and application forms for courses.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://polhn.org/forms|title=POLHN website-forms|work=polhn}}</ref>
It has partnerships with many organisations, allowing members to complete certification programs. There are also general courses unrelated to any certification program, such as Patient Safety, Risk Communications, Diabetes, and Psycho-social Response in Humanitarian Disasters. These take between 20 and 60 hours to complete, with automatic assessment of activities and exams.
Since its inception, POLHN has undergone various steps to expand and improve. These have included external reviews, for instance by the [[WHO Collaborating Centres|WHO Collaborating Centre]] at the [[University of Technology Sydney]] and Hezel Associates.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.hezel.com/what-we-ve-done/past-projects/226-who-wpro-pohln-nursing|title=Hezel Associates - WHO-WPRO Evaluation of POHLN Nursing Education (2010-2011)}}</ref>
===Goals===
POLHN has three main goals: # To provide access to quality, equitable, efficient and effective e-learning platforms that support health workers to maintain relevant skills and in so doing to enable countries to have a more sustainable and responsive skill mix; # To assist regulatory and ministerial bodies to develop relevant policies for continuing professional development (CPD) of health workforces; and # To support in building and sustaining the capacity of institutions to provide appropriate and accredited curricula through collaborative partnerships with health professionals, service providers, professional bodies, healthcare organisations, education and research entities.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://polhn.org/about-polhn|title=POLHN website - About us|work=polhn}}</ref>
==The POLHN community==
The POLHN platform facilitates learning through an interactive environment, where students can access information, communicate with students and teachers, and complete course modules and assessments. Over 30,000<ref>{{cite web|url=https://polhn.org/about-polhn|title=POLHN website}}</ref> health workers have accessed POLHN across various cadres.
===Learning centres===
A key component of the POLHN community is its learning centres. These are physical locations where health workers in Pacific island countries can have easy access to courses. To date, POLHN has 54 internet connected learning and development centres in 15 Pacific island countries.
Learning centres are located in 14 countries: * [[American Samoa]]; * [[Cook Islands]]; * [[Federated States of Micronesia]]; * [[Fiji]]; * [[Guam]] * [[Kiribati]]; * [[Marshall Islands]]; * [[Nauru]]; * [[Niue]]; * [[Palau]]; * [[Samoa]]; * [[Solomon Islands]]; * [[Tonga]]; * [[Tuvalu]]; and * [[Vanuatu]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://polhn.org/learning-centres|title=POLHN website - Learning Centres}}</ref>
Pacific Ministries of Health have appointed 40+ country coordinators and focal points to manage POLHN in-country activities.
===Online media===
====Social media====
POLHN also has a strong community across social media. It regularly and actively engages through platforms such as Facebook <ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.facebook.com/polhn|title=POLHN Facebook page|work=POLHN}}</ref> and LinkedIn.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.linkedin.com/company/pacific-open-learning-health-net/|title=POLHN on LinkedIn|work=POLHN}}</ref> These are managed in-house at the WHO Division of Technical Support in Suva, Fiji.
====The POLHN blog====
In 2017, POLHN launched its online blog. Since then, several pieces have been published under the general theme of health education.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://polhn.org/blog|title=POLHN website - blog|work=polhn}}</ref> This has included success stories on POLHN students across the Pacific,<ref>{{cite web|url=https://polhn.org/success-stories|title=POLHN website - success stories|work=POLHN}}</ref> as well as the latest news on POLHN.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://polhn.org/latest-news|title=POLHN website - latest news|work=POLHN}}</ref>
====POLHN newsletter====
In addition to this, POLHN has a popular newsletter, which is sent out regularly to students and staff regarding all the current events related to POLHN, such as scholarship opportunities, new blog articles, and the latest courses.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://polhn.org/subscribe|title=POLHN website - subscribe to our newsletter|work=polhn}}</ref> The blog also offers the opportunity for members of the POLHN community to write their own articles and post comments.
== Partnership approach ==
POLHN is a partnership between [[WHO]] and Pacific Ministries of Health. POLHN works with regional academic institutions; course providers; academic institutions and development partners to develops and provides continuing education opportunities to health professionals in the Pacific.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://iris.wpro.who.int/bitstream/handle/10665.1/11817/WPR_2015_DPS_001_eng.pdf/|title=POLHN Handbook|work=polhn}}</ref> POLHN hosts different course categories: * Self-paced; * Instructor-led; * Blended: work-based learning; * Mentor-based teaching; and * Face-to-face on-site workshops.
===Sponsorship===
Each semester, POLHN sponsors approximately 100 staff from Pacific ministries of health to take instructor-led postgraduate courses. Postgraduate certificates, diplomas and masters programmes are all available. These can be completed without students leaving their communities.
Primarily, POLHN's partnership approach involves POLHN's partners offering sponsorship are: * [[Fiji National University]]; * [[University of Fiji]]; * Pacific Paramedical Training Centre; and * [[Penn Foster College|Penn Foster Dental School]].
===Self-paced courses===
POLHN's self-paced courses are also put together with the assistance of its partners. Some courses are created in-house at the WHO Secretariat in Suva, Fiji. Others are made in cooperation with partner institutions, including the [[University of Queensland]].<ref>For instance, the [[University of Queensland]] produced the self-paced course entitled "Health Information Management", found here: https://polhn.org/courses/health-information-management</ref>
==List of partners==
===University of Fiji=== POLHN sponsors registered nurses in the Pacific to undertake a Bachelor of Nursing Bridging programme at the [[University of Fiji]] (also known as UniFiji). This allows nurses with a Diploma in Nursing to upgrade their qualification to a bachelor's degree. This new initiative has been widely praised in the media in Fiji, where POLHN sponsorship for nursing at UniFiji is seen as a real opportunity to take the skills of nurses in the Pacific to a whole new level.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://fijisun.com.fj/2018/01/28/unifiji-offers-bachelor-of-nursing-course/|newspaper=Fiji Sun|title=UniFiji Offers Bachelor Of Nursing Course}}</ref>
===Fiji National University (FNU)===
POLHN annually sponsors over 100 health professionals across the Pacific to take postgraduate courses in public health and health services management through FNU.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.fsm.ac.fj/|title=FNU Website|work=polhn}}</ref> Programs are available at postgraduate certificate, diploma and masters levels and can be completed by health workers without leaving their communities.
POLHN sponsors certificates in [[epidemiology|applied epidemiology]], health research, [[health service management]], and [[public health]]. The Master's in Public Health is particularly popular.<ref>{{cite news|title=POLHN’s free online courses improve education opportunities for Pacific health workers|url=https://www.pina.com.fj/index.php?p=pacnews&m=read&o=7327804345b625e6573dbf19aabbc5|newspaper=Pacific Islands News Association}}</ref>
===Pacific Paramedical Training Centre (PPTC)===
The PPTC provides technical training and development assistance to clinical laboratories and blood transfusion services of the Pacific region. Mostly runs training courses in Wellington but retains flexibility to run in-country courses, short-term attachments to NZ medical labs and offers on-line courses through POLHN.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://pptc.org.nz/pptc-activities-2|title=PPTC Activity|work=polhn}}</ref> They also have a quality management component (Regional External Quality Assurance Programme). POLHN sponsors around 40 laboratory technicians to take PPTC's Diploma in Medical Laboratory Science.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://pptc.org.nz/wp-content/uploads/2014/11/Selection-Criteria-for-POLHN-Courses.pdf|title=PPTC Selection Criteria|work=polhn}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://pptc.org.nz/|title=PPTC Website|work=polhn}}</ref> POLHN and PPTC work is benefiting laboratory assistants across the Pacific in completion of their Diplomas in Medical Laboratory Science.<ref>{{Cite web|title=Strengthening laboratory services in the Pacific|url=http://www.wpro.who.int/whocc_forum/highlights/news/20160914-strengthening-lab-services-pacific/en/}}</ref> These diplomas include generally involve up to 8 courses over 2 years, include ones in laboratory technology, biochemistry, blood bank technology, hematology, immunology, microbiology, and laboratory diagnosis of STIs.
===Penn Foster Dental School===
Certification awarded by Penn Foster Career School<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.pennfoster.edu/programs-and-degrees/medical-and-health-careers/dental-assistant-career-diploma|title=Penn Foster Website|work=polhn}}</ref> in collaboration with Pacific Basin Dental Association (PBDA) and WHO/POLHN. This involves 9 modules in 9 months (self-paced), with face-to-face validation of skills via PBDA.
As of 2016, the countries involved are [[American Samoa]], [[Federated States of Micronesia]] (FSM), [[Republic of Marshall Islands]]
===Lippincott: The Online Nursing Center===
Lippincott provides over 1000 continuing education resources developed by nurses for nurses, POLHN assists by providing free access to fee-based courses.
===Medscape (Education)===
Medscape education<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.medscape.com/|title=Medscape Website|work=polhn}}</ref> provides CPD courses in over 30 health specialities. The courses are accredited by the Accreditation Council for Continuing Medical Education.
===Global Health eLearning Center (GHeL)===
POLHN links with GHeL<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.globalhealthlearning.org/services|title=Global Health eLearning Center - Services|last=|first=|date=|work=polhn|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref> in order for health professionals in the Pacific to access over 50 short courses in public health, developed by USAID specifically for health professionals working in low-resource settings. In the Pacific region, through endorsement from the Pacific Open Learning Health Net (POLHN), GHeL courses are accepted CPD requirements for 30,000 health workers from 15 Pacific island countries.<ref>{{Cite web|title=NEW Fact Sheet on How GHeL is Used in Training and Accreditation!|url=https://www.globalhealthlearning.org/announcement/new-fact-sheet-ghel-accreditation}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Distance Learning Bolsters Knowledge and Skills of Current and Future Health Providers|url=https://www.globalhealthlearning.org/sites/default/files/page/GHEL%20Brief_Nov2017_0.pdf|newspaper=Global Health E-Learning Brief}}</ref>
=== Secretariat at the WHO Pacific Division ===
POLHN has developed a conventional relationship with fourteen of the twenty two Pacific countries and areas and has established forty POLHN centres in 14 of those countries. The POLHN centres are usually located in or near hospitals or nursing schools. Most of the learning centres are equipped with internet connected computers, printers, scanners and video projection equipment.
==References==
{{Reflist|30em}}
==External links== *[http://polhn.org/ POLHN Official Website] *[https://www.pennfoster.edu/programs-and-degrees/medical-and-health-careers/dental-assistant-career-diploma Penn Foster Online Dental Assistant Training] *[http://www.fnu.ac.fj/new/ Fiji National University] *[http://pptc.org.nz/ Pacific Paramedical Training Centre] *[https://www.unifiji.ac.fj/ University of Fiji]
{{DEFAULTSORT:POLHN}} [[Category:Health education]] [[Category:Online education]] [[Category:Open educational resources]] [[Category:Educational websites]] [[Category:Learning management systems]]

{{Infobox publisher | image = | parent = | status = | founded = 1820 | founder = William Pickering | successor = | country = [[United Kingdom]] | headquarters = [[London]], [[United Kingdom]] | distribution = | keypeople = | publications = Academic monographs, critical editions, thematic source collections | topics = Humanities and social sciences | genre = | imprints = | revenue = | numemployees = | nasdaq = | url = https://www.routledge.com/posts/5009 }} '''Pickering & Chatto''' is an [[Imprint (trade name)|imprint]] of [[Routledge]] which publishes in the [[humanities]] and [[social sciences]], specializing in monographs, critical editions (works, diaries, correspondence) and thematic source collections.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thebookseller.com/news/rivals-attack-oup-and-cup.html |title= Rivals attack OUP and CUP |publisher= thebookseller.com |date= 2008-04-24 |accessdate=2014-03-14}}</ref> Pickering & Chatto's academic monographs have an international reputation and its critical editions and source collections are critically acclaimed.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.docenotas.com/portada/publicaciones/libros/las-metaforas-musicales-del-poder |title=Las metáforas musicales del poser |publisher=docenotas.com |date= |accessdate=2014-03-14}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.academicrightspress.com/content/view/74/106/ |title=Pickering & Chatto Women's Studies Collection |publisher=academicrightspress.com |date= |accessdate=2014-03-11 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140714192855/http://www.academicrightspress.com/content/view/74/106/ |archivedate=2014-07-14 |df= }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nlx.com/collections/157/ |title= Works of Daniel Defoe. Pickering & Chatto Edition. |publisher= nlx.com |date= |accessdate=2014-11-03}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url= http://www.cambridge.org/about-us/media/press-releases/cambridge-university-press-announces-new-partner-digital-publishing-platform/ |title=Cambridge University Press announces new partner for digital publishing platform |publisher= Cambridge University Press (cambridge.org) |date= |accessdate=2015-05-01}}</ref> Pickering & Chatto is regarded as "the pre-eminent publisher of critical editions in the humanities and social sciences".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://alexanderstreet.com/products/romanticism-redefined-pickering-chatto-and-wordsworth-circle/ |title= Romanticism Redefined: Pickering & Chatto and The Wordsworth Circle |publisher= alexanderstreet.com |date= |accessdate=2014-11-03}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bars.ac.uk/publishing/Romanticeraredefined.htm |title=The Romantic Era Redefined |publisher= The British Association for Romantic Studies (bars.ac.uk) |date =|accessdate= 2014-03-14}}</ref>
== History ==
The origins of the company can be traced back to [[William Pickering (publisher)|William Pickering]] (1796–1854) who set up as an antiquarian bookseller and publisher in 1820. After William Pickering’s death, the business was carried on by his son, Basil Montagu Pickering.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.oxforddnb.com/view/article/22213 |title=Pickering, William (1796–1854) |publisher=Oxford Dictionary of National Biography, Oxford University Press, 2004; online edn, Jan 2008 |date=|accessdate=2014-03-14}}</ref> On his death, in 1878, it was purchased by Andrew Chatto (1841–1913), one of the founding partners of [[Chatto and Windus]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.open.ac.uk/researchprojects/makingbritain/content/chatto-windus |title=Chatto & Windus |publisher=The Open University |date=|accessdate=2013-05-09}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.randomhouse.co.uk/about-us/about-us/companies/uk-companies-and-imprints/vintage-publishing/chatto-windus |title=Chatto & Windus |publisher=Randomhouse.co.uk |date=|accessdate=2014-11-14}} </ref> By the early twentieth century Pickering & Chatto was solely concerned with antiquarian book selling.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.oxforddnb.com/view/article/47445 |title=Chatto, Andrew (1840–1913) |publisher=Oxford Dictionary of National Biography, Oxford University Press, 2004; online edn, Jan 2009 |date= |accessdate=2014-05-09}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2013/01/05/world/europe/william-rees-mogg-former-editor-of-the-times-of-london-dies-at-84.html?_r=0 |title=William Rees-Mogg, Ex-Editor of The Times of London, Dies at 84 |publisher =nytimes.com |date=2013-01-04 |accessdate=2014-03-14}}</ref> Lord [[William Rees-Mogg]] bought Pickering & Chatto in 1981.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/media/2012/dec/29/william-rees-mogg-obituary |title=Lord Rees-Mogg obituary |publisher=Guardian.co.uk |date=2012-12-29 |accessdate=2013-05-09}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/obituaries/politics-obituaries/9771814/Lord-Rees-Mogg.html |title=Lord Rees-Mogg |publisher=telegraph.co.uk |date=2012-12-30 |accessdate=2014-03-14}}</ref>
In 1983 he re-established Pickering & Chatto (Publishers) Limited as an independent publishing house, serving as chairman and proprietor.<ref name=engass>{{cite book|last1=Baker|first1=William|last2=Lucas|first2=Helen|last3=Treharne|first3=Elaine|title=The English Association: One Hundred Years on|date=30 December 2006|publisher=[[English Association]]|location=[[Leicester]]|isbn=9780900232251|page=50|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=wvMvAQAAMAAJ|accessdate=21 November 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/9770732/William-Rees-Mogg.html |title=William Rees-Mogg |publisher=telegraph.co.uk |date=2010-12-29 |accessdate=2014-03-14}}</ref> In 1993 the antiquarian bookselling business became an entirely separate enterprise and there is now no connection between the two companies.<ref>{{cite web|url= http://www.pickering-chatto.com/PC/Home.html |title=Pickering & Chatto Antiquarian Booksellers |publisher= |date=|accessdate=2013-05-09}}</ref> Pickering & Chatto was based in [[Bloomsbury]], [[London]], [[United Kingdom]]<ref>{{cite web|url= http://www.publishersglobal.com/directory/publisher-profile/5921/ |title=Pickering & Chatto Publishers |publisher=Publishersglobal.com |date= |accessdate=2013-05-09}}</ref> until March, 2015, when it was acquired by the [[Taylor & Francis]] Group and became an [[Imprint (trade name)|imprint]] of [[Routledge]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bertolimitchell.co.uk/dealsummary_Pickering_Chatto.html |title=Bertoli Mitchell arranges the sale of Pickering and Chatto to Taylor & Francis |publisher= bertolimitchell.co.uk |date =|accessdate= 2015-05-01}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.routledge.com/posts/5009 |title= Routledge Welcomes Pickering & Chatto |publisher= routledge.com |date =|accessdate=2015-09-11}}</ref>
== Footnotes == {{reflist|2}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Pickering and Chatto Publishers}} [[Category:Educational book publishing companies]] [[Category:Academic publishing companies]]

revision.text:
[[Image:ROAR_Pin.jpg|thumb|right|alt=R.O.A.R. Pin|R.O.A.R. Pin]] {{More citations needed|date=June 2016}} '''Restore Our Alienated Rights''' ('''ROAR''') was an organization formed in [[Boston, Massachusetts]] by [[Louise Day Hicks]] in 1974.<ref>[http://www.cityofboston.gov/images_documents/Guide%20to%20the%20Louise%20Day%20Hicks%20papers_tcm3-37481.pdf Guide to the Louise Day Hicks records]</ref> Opposed to [[desegregation busing]] of Boston's public school students, the group protested the federally-mandated order to integrate Boston Public Schools by staging formal, sometimes violent protests. It remained active from 1974 until 1976.<ref name=":0">{{cite news|title=’Militant Mothers’: Boston, Busing, and the Bicentennial of 1976.” Historical Journal of Massachusetts|last1=Nutter|first1=Kathleen|date=2010|work=Historical Journal of Massachusetts|publisher=Boston Globe|volume=38 Àissue=2}}</ref>
== Background Information == Many citizens felt the racial imbalance in Boston needed to be improved. The African-Americans of Boston had been fighting for equality in black and white public schools for decades before the creation of the Racial Imbalance Act or the formation of ROAR. Due to the inherent segregation within Boston, many schools were composed of either majority white or majority black students. This led to the white schools receiving more funding per student and having newer educational resources while black schools were receiving statistically much less funding and were typically of inferior quality than schools in primarily white districts. There was apparent segregation which occurred by chance legally. This form of segregation, known as "de facto" segregation was not intentional. Rather, it occurred by circumstance.<ref name=":1">{{Cite web|url=http://bosdesca.omeka.net/background|title=Background · Stark & Subtle Divisions: A Collaborative History of Segregation in Boston|website=bosdesca.omeka.net|language=en-US|access-date=2017-10-26}}</ref>
One of the members of the Boston School Committee, [[Louise Day Hicks]], was to become the founder of ROAR. The committee itself denied any accusations of inequity amongst white and black students. Hicks spoke outwardly against the desegregation of schools. The [[NAACP]] was not willing to let this segregation continue and filed a lawsuit against the Boston School Committee; this was the beginning of the [[Morgan v. Hennigan|Tallulah Morgan v. James Hennigan]] case which would eventually bring about forced busing. On June 21, 1974, [[Wendell Arthur Garrity Jr.|Judge Garrity]] ruled that the Committee was to create a plan to desegregate their schools. When the committee failed to provide such an idea, the federal court became involved. By federal decision, students were to be bused to schools in different districts to decrease the level of inequal education students were receiving.<ref name=":1" />
Those who opposed the forced busing, which happened to be the majority of whites, especially mothers, in Boston, retaliated with protests. They eventually organized to create the infamous ROAR. While some of their concerns were legitimate, the organization was ultimately pro-segregation of schools. Not all members were definitive racists, but there was a connection between the group and racism as some of the members spoke outwardly against blacks.<ref name=":1" /> Initially a small group of females, they quickly gained local popularity as many locals shared their opinions. The act of forced busing was seen as a populist movement that potentially threatened the traditional values that the women of ROAR held.<ref name=":0" /> The fusing of mainly African-American and white districts could dissipate the borders between two very different neighborhoods that held different values, leading to certain groups feeling alienated.<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=3Czw8VQnuGwC&pg=PA33#v=onepage&q&f=false|title=Groundwork: Local Black Freedom Movements in America|last=Theoharis|first=Jeanne|last2=Woodard|first2=Komozi|date=2005|publisher=NYU Press|isbn=9780814782859|language=en}}</ref>
==Founding==
[[Louise Day Hicks|Louise Day-Hicks]] created "Save Boston Committee" in February 1974 with an agenda to restore "the custodial rights of parents over their children".<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://bosdesca.omeka.net/exhibits/show/roar-anti-busing-group|title=ROAR: The Anti-Busing group with the Loudest Voice · Stark & Subtle Divisions: A Collaborative History of Segregation in Boston|website=bosdesca.omeka.net|language=en-US|access-date=2017-10-26}}</ref> She believed it was unfair for the government to force all public schools to desegregate, claiming it was neither a viable nor a beneficial way to improve American society and education. The group was later renamed ROAR to oppose the Racial Imbalance Act in 1974. The busing change in their eyes was "a total disaster".<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://archive.boston.com/news/globe/obituaries/articles/2006/09/12/elvira_pixie_palladino_74_fierce_foe_of_imposed_busing/|title=Elvira 'Pixie' Palladino, 74, fierce foe of imposed busing - The Boston Globe|website=archive.boston.com|language=en|access-date=2017-10-26}}</ref> Hicks changed the name by the summer to ROAR. She used her position as a mother to rally others into her cause, arguing that the government needed to take a different approach if they wanted a stable nation. Some Americans, namely white mothers believed they were righteous in their cause and that they just wanted to keep the school environment running properly as much as possible.
==Purpose== The group's purpose was to fight off U.S. Federal Judge W. Arthur Garrity's [[court order]] requiring the city of Boston to implement desegregation busing — an order intended to eliminate ''[[de facto]]'' [[racial segregation]] in its [[Public school (government funded)|public schools]]. To supporters, ROAR's purpose was its namesake; i.e., to protect the "vanishing rights" of white citizens. To its many opponents, however, ROAR was a symbol of mass [[racism]] coalesced into a single organization. ROAR was composed primarily of women, and its leaders argued that "the issue of forced busing is a women's issue."<ref name="Banks Nutter 2010 Militant Mothers">{{cite journal|last=Banks Nutter|first=Kathleen|date=Fall 2010|title=“Militant Mothers”: Boston, Busing, and the Bicentennial of 1976|url=http://www.wsc.mass.edu/mhj/pdfs/militant%20mothers.pdf|journal=Historical Journal of Massachusetts|volume=38 |issue=1|pages=52–75|access-date=April 6, 2017}}</ref>
On April 3, 1974, the committee organized a 20,000 person march from Boston City Hall Plaza to the State House.<ref name="Banks Nutter 2010 Militant Mothers"/> On March 19, 1975, 1,200 ROAR members marched in Washington DC to generate national support for their cause.<ref name=":3">{{cite journal |last=Morgan |first=Marilyn |date=March 18, 2017 |title=Roaring for Rights: Louise Day Hicks, Women & the Anti-Busing Movement |url=http://www.archivespublichistory.org/?tag=restore-our-alienated-rights |journal=Archives & Public History at UMass Boston |access-date=April 6, 2017 }}</ref>
==Notable members== [[Louise Day Hicks]], the founder of the organization, firmly opposed the [[racial integration]] of schools in Boston for ten years beforehand.<ref>Mydians, Seth. "Woman Guiding Spirit in Boston School Fight." The Register Guard, 7 Nov. 1974, p. 14A,</ref> Her office served as the headquarters for ROAR, she led a majority of protests, and she responded to all letters addressed to ROAR.<ref name=":2">Sherman, Rachel. "ROAR: The Anti-Busing group with the Loudest Voice." Stark & Subtle Divisions: A Collaborative History of Segregation in Boston, bosdesca.omeka.net/exhibits/show/roar-anti-busing-group.</ref> Once a fight between Hicks and fellow member Pixie Palladino broke out, members' trust in Hicks began to diminish.
Palladino was considered to be more radical than Hicks.<ref name=":2" /> In January 1975, Palladino and eighty ROAR women stormed into a governor's commission on the status of women, dressed in "Stop Forced Busing" T-shirts.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.southcoasttoday.com/article/20060913/news/309139969|title=Pixie Palladino, opponent of school desegregation|last=Press|first=The Associated|work=southcoasttoday.com|access-date=2017-10-26|language=en}}</ref> On March 10, 1976, Palladino began to create her own group, "United ROAR", which catered to beliefs that were more moderate than those of Hicks.<ref name=":2" />
Fran Johnnene was one of ROAR's most influential members. Johnnene was mostly responsible for holding meetings at her house in Hyde Park, rounding up neighbors and community members.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://sparechangenews.net/2016/03/raymond-flynn/|title=Raymond Flynn: The South Boston insider who struggled to keep his alma mater open and ascended to political prominence - Spare Change News|website=sparechangenews.net|language=en-US|access-date=2017-10-26}}</ref> Johnnene was also involved with the less radical anti-busing group, the Massachusetts Citizens Against Forced Busing, in February 1974. Towards the end of 1975, Johnnene left ROAR due to the increased radicalism.<ref name=":2" />
A majority of the group's members were white Boston housewives, known as "militant mothers."<ref name="Banks Nutter 2010 Militant Mothers" />
== Activities == There were instances of both violent and peaceful protest from the organization ROAR. During a protest, a wooden bus was burned as a representation of the forced busing policy (Powell). There were also occasions on which school children and parents alike pelted the buses coming from predominantly African-American areas (Gellerman). Protester signs often displayed racial slurs such as, 'Nigger Go Home,' and depicted monkeys (Gellerman). On December 11, 1974, at South Boston High, Michael Faith, a white student was stabbed by a black student by the name of James White. Hicks, present at the scene, attempted to calm the crowd, most of which belonging in ROAR. At that time, she prioritized the black students' safety on their way back home.
However, members also protested in peaceful ways. For example, in the time immediately following the desegregation, majority of white children did not attend school in both the formerly African-American schools and historically white schools (Gellerman). They reenacted the Boston Massacre to symbolize their empathy with the oppressed inhabitants of colonial America (Lukas). On April 3, 1974, over 20,000 ROAR protesters marched on the State House to show their distaste for desegregation busing.<ref name=":0" /> On March 19, 1975, 1,200 members of ROAR marched on Washington DC to gain national recognition for their cause and possibly an amendment placed into the constitution that would illegal desegregation busing.<ref name=":3" />
== Societal Response == By the year 1975, ROAR shifts its focus from busing to feminine issues, including participating in the signing for the year 1975 to be known as "International Women's Year." At that point, the forced busing act was seen more as an attack on women, specifically mothers. ROAR however remained ignored by the government, but continued to protest fervently. Though the media particularly the Boston Globe, often portrayed the group as racist, ROAR leader Virginia Sheehy states that their issues are mainly class-based. Sheehy argued by stating that she initially worked alongside black women in the Home and School Association prior to the forced busing issue. On the other hand, [[The Real Paper]], a local newspaper company stated that the ROAR group is truly fighting for their traditional values. Overall, ROAR helped to consolidate the conservatism movement in the following year.<ref name=":0" />
==See also== *[[Civil Rights Movement]] *[[Desegregation busing in the United States]] *[[Boston busing crisis]] *[[Louise Day Hicks]]
==Further reading==
*[[Louise Day Hicks]] [http://www.cityofboston.gov/images_documents/Guide%20to%20the%20Louise%20Day%20Hicks%20papers_tcm3-37481.pdf papers] at the Boston City Archives *[[Francesca Johnnene]] [http://archives.cityofboston.gov/repositories/2/resources/62 papers] at the Boston City Archives
==References== {{reflist}}
[[Category:Defunct American political movements]] [[Category:History of Boston]] [[Category:History of civil rights in the United States]] [[Category:Political history of Massachusetts]] [[Category:Racism in the United States]] [[Category:School segregation in the United States]] [[Category:Student transport]] [[Category:1974 establishments in Massachusetts]] [[Category:1976 disestablishments in Massachusetts]] [[Category:Organizations established in 1974]] [[Category:Organizations disestablished in 1976]]

{{nn|date=April 2014}} '''Student activities''' or '''campus activities''' is a broad term describing most student-focused [[extracurricular]] clubs and programs at a [[college]] or [[university]]. Student activities are generally designed to allow students to get more involved and offer them opportunities in leadership, social responsibility, citizenship, volunteerism, and student employment. <ref>{{Cite web|url = http://studentaffairs.psu.edu/hub/|title = Student Affairs @ Penn State Union and Student Activities|date = 2015|accessdate =January 22, 2017 |website = |publisher = [[Penn State]]|last = |first = }}</ref> These activities are typically overseen by a Director of Student Activities, Student Affairs, or Student Engagement who often holds a [[master's degree]] in [[student development]] or a comparable field. Program directors often provide guidance for clubs, set standards for student run organizations, and can also help network with other institutions through organizations like the [[National Association for Campus Activities]] (NACA) or the [[Association for the Promotion of Campus Activities]] (APCA).<ref>[http://www.apca.com APCA website]</ref>
== Types of Student Activities == Student activities generally fall under one or more of the following categories:
=== Academic === [[Academic]] student activities refer to clubs and programming specifically focusing on scholarly endeavors. This can take the form of [[Academic majors|major]]-based or area of study-based clubs or programs and events designed to educate students in any scholarly subject matter.
Some examples of academic student activities would be: * Accounting Society * Language Clubs * Art History Club * [[Public Relations Student Society of America|Public Relations Student Society]] * Pre-Law Society
=== Civic Engagement === [[Civic engagement]] generally refer to clubs and programming focusing on creating positive societal change. Some of these activities may also fall under the academic category as these activities may work to educate students about [[social issues]] and the importance of getting involved.
Some examples of civic engagement activities would be: * Action in Africa * [[Colleges Against Cancer]] * [[Lions Club]] School Chapters * [[Circle K International]] * Political Party-Based Clubs * College/University Day of Service
=== Diversity/Cultural === [[Cultural diversity|Diversity]] or cultural student activities generally refer to clubs and programming focusing on representation of [[minority groups]] on campus. These activities may also fall under the academic category as these activities work to educate students on cultural differences.
Some examples of diversity/cultural activities would be: * Black Student Union * Asian Pacific Student Association * Feminist Club * Queer-Straight Alliance * Disability Alliance * [[Diversity training|Diversity Training]] Programs
=== Honor Societies === [[Honor society|Honor societies]] are organizations that recognize academic excellence among students. These organizations are usually exclusive to students who have excelled academically, based on scholastic ranking and/or grade point average. Honor societies are usually national or even international organizations that have established chapters at certain colleges and universities.
Some examples of honor societies are: * National Society of Leadership & Success * [[National Society of Collegiate Scholars]] * [[Alpha Kappa Delta]] * [[Mortar Board]] National College Senior Honor Society
=== Leisure === Leisure activities refer to clubs and programs that give student opportunities to connect with stunts with similar hobbies and simply to take time pure enjoyment and fun.
Some examples of leisure activities would be: * A cappella Groups * Improv Troupes * Fan Clubs * Cooking Club
=== Recreational === Recreational activities refer to clubs and programming that involve some form of physical activity.
Some examples of recreational activities would be: * Dance Team * [[Intramural Sports]] Teams * Surfing Club * Sports Tournaments
=== Religious/Spiritual === Religious/spiritual activities refer to clubs and programming that allow students to connect with other students of similar faiths, practice their chosen faith, and/or learn about other faiths. Many schools have a faith center where these sorts of programs take place.
Some examples of religious/spiritual activities would be: * Interfaith Council * Fellowship of Christian Athletes * International Justice Mission * Latter Day Saint Student Association
=== Student-Run Event Planning Board === A student-run event planning board is a group of students that work under a faculty advisor to plan events for students, such as concerts, speakers, dances, movie screenings, etc. Generally, this board is also responsible for hosting special tradition-type events. These types of groups are often funded by grants from the college or university.
=== Student-Run Businesses === Student-run businesses can be any sort of business that has an affiliation with the college or university and is almost completely, if not completely, run by student workers.
Some examples of student-run businesses would be: * College/University Radio Station * College/University Local Television Station * Production Company * Advertising Firm
=== Greek Organizations === [[Greek organizations]] include [[fraternities and sororities]], which are exclusive social organizations. These groups are referred to as 'Greek' for their names are made up of two or 3 greek letters. These organizations generally focus on the betterment and empowerment of members. Students go through a 'bidding' process in order to be initiated into one of these organizations. Universities and colleges also have Panhellenic and Inter-Fraternity Councils, which act as the governing body over Greek organizations. Some [[honor societies]] can also be considered Greek organizations due to their Greek letter affiliation, however these organizations tend to be co-ed, while fraternities are all-male groups and sororities are all-female groups.
Some examples of Greek organizations are: * [[Alpha Gamma Delta]] * [[Delta Tau Delta]] * [[Pi Beta Phi]] * [[Alpha Epsilon Pi]]
==References== {{Reflist}}
[[Category:Student culture]]
